verse.text: Paul, an [xref]a[/xref]apostle of Christ Jesus through the [note]1[/note]will of God, and [xref]b[/xref]Timothy the brother, to the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]church of God which is [note]3[/note]in Corinth, [note]4[/note]with all the saints who are in the whole of [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]Achaia:
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 1[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 1[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 1[/link].
See note [link]2[sup]7[/sup] in 1 Cor. 1[/link].
A province of the Roman Empire south of Macedonia. It constituted the greater part of today's Greece, where the city of Corinth is.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
[xref]a[/xref]Blessed be the [xref]b[/xref]God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of [note]1[/note]compassions and God of all [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]comfort;
verse.note: Or, mercies, pity, sympathy.

Comfort implies being cheered. A title such as [i]the Father of compassions[/i] and God of all comfort is ascribed here to God because this Epistle is one of comfort and encouragement, written by the apostle after he had been comforted and encouraged by the repentance of the Corinthian believers. The rebuking and condemning in the first Epistle to the Corinthians were intended to cause the Corinthian believers to turn back to and stress Christ; the comfort and encouragement in this Epistle were intended to bring them to experience and enjoy Christ.

verse.text: Who [xref]a[/xref]comforts us in all our [xref]b[/xref]affliction that we may be [note]1[/note]able to comfort those who are in every affliction through the [xref]c[/xref]comforting with which we ourselves are comforted by God.
verse.note: We must first experience God's comforting; then we are able to comfort others with the comfort from God that we have experienced.[br][br]The first Epistle to the Corinthians was the apostle's argument, an argument that defeated and subdued the distracted and confused Corinthians. Now the second Epistle brought them back into the experience of Christ, who was the subject of his argument in the first Epistle. Hence, the second Epistle is more experiential, more subjective, and deeper than the first. In the first, Christ, the Spirit with our spirit, the church, and the gifts are covered as the major subjects. In the second, Christ, the Spirit with our spirit, and the church are developed further, but the gifts are not even mentioned. The gifts are replaced in this book by the ministry, which is constituted with, and produced and formed by, the experiences of the riches of Christ gained through sufferings, consuming pressures, and the killing work of the cross. This Epistle gives us a pattern, an example, of how the killing of the cross works, how Christ is wrought into our being, and how we become the expression of Christ. These processes constitute the ministers of Christ and produce the ministry for God's new covenant. The first Epistle deals negatively with the gifts; the second speaks positively about the ministry. The church needs the ministry much more than the gifts. The ministry is for ministering the Christ whom we have experienced, whereas the gifts are just for teaching the doctrines concerning Christ. Not the gifts but the ministry produced and formed by the experience of the sufferings, the afflictions, of Christ is the proof that the apostles are ministers of Christ.

verse.text: For even as the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sufferings of [note]2[/note]the Christ abound unto us, so through [note]2[/note]the Christ our comfort also abounds.
verse.note: Not sufferings for Christ but Christ's own sufferings as shared by His disciples ([link]Matt. 20:22[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:10[/link]; [link]Col. 1:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:13[/link]).

[i]The Christ[/i] here is a designation of the condition of Christ; it is not a name (Darby). Here it refers to the suffering Christ, who suffered afflictions for His Body according to God's will. The apostles participated in the sufferings of such a Christ, and through such a Christ they received comfort.

verse.text: But whether we are [xref]a[/xref]afflicted, it is for your comforting and salvation; or whether we are comforted, it is for your comforting, which operates in the endurance of the same sufferings which we also suffer.
And our hope for you is firm, knowing that as you are partakers of the [xref]a[/xref]sufferings, so also [i]you are[/i] of the comfort.

For we do not want you to be [xref]a[/xref]ignorant, brothers, of our affliction which befell [i]us[/i] in [xref]b[/xref]Asia, that we were excessively [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]burdened, beyond [i]our[/i] power, so that we [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]despaired even of [note]3[/note]living.
verse.note: I.e., weighed down, pressed down. The same Greek word as in [link]5:4[/link].
In Greek the same word as for [i]utterly without a way out[/i] in [link]4:8[/link].
Or, life.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Indeed we ourselves had the [note]2[/note]response of [xref]a[/xref]death in ourselves, that we should [xref]b[/xref]not base our [xref]c[/xref]confidence on ourselves but [xref]d[/xref]on [note]3[/note]God, who [xref]e[/xref]raises the dead;
verse.note: In this book the apostle is presented as a pattern of a person living Christ in five aspects for the church: (1) not basing his confidence on himself but on God, who raises the dead ([link]v. 9[/link]), which includes related matters such as conducting himself in the world not in fleshly wisdom but in the grace of God ([link]v. 12[/link]) and being one with the unchanging Christ of the faithful God ([link]vv. 18-20[/link]); (2) being attached to Christ, anointed and sealed by His Spirit, and captured, subdued, and led by Him to scatter His savor ([link]vv. 21-22[/link]; [link]2:14-16[/link]); (3) being sufficient of Christ as the spiritual alphabet to write living letters with the life-giving Spirit of the living God ([link]3:3-6[/link]); (4) having the shining of the glory of the new covenant ([link]3:7-11[/link]); and (5) being transformed into the image of the Lord from glory to glory, even as from the Lord Spirit, by beholding and reflecting like a mirror His glory with unveiled face ([link]3:16-18[/link]).

Or, answer. When the apostles were under the pressure of affliction, despairing even of life, they might have asked themselves what the issue of their suffering would be. The answer or response was "death." This led them to the vital decision not to base their confidence on themselves but on God, who raises the dead.

The experience of death ushers us into the experience of resurrection. Resurrection is the very God, who resurrects the dead. The working of the cross terminates our self that we may experience God in resurrection. The experience of the cross always issues in the enjoyment of the God of resurrection. Such experience produces and forms the ministry ([link]vv. 4-6[/link]). This is further described in [link]4:7-12[/link].

verse.text: Who has [xref]a[/xref]delivered us out of so great a death, and [note]1[/note]will deliver [i]us;[/i] in whom we have [xref]b[/xref]hoped that He will also yet deliver [i]us,[/i]
verse.note: Referring to the immediate future (indicating continuity).

verse.text: If you also [note]1[/note]help in [i]this[/i] by [xref]a[/xref]petition on our behalf, that for the [note]2[/note]gift to us through many, [xref]b[/xref]thanks may be given by many [note]3[/note]persons on our behalf.
verse.note: Or, work together. This must refer to the believers' coordinating with and rendering help in God's deliverance and the apostles' hope mentioned in the preceding verse.

Referring to the grace given ([link]v. 12[/link]), the resurrected Christ Himself, who is the grace that the apostles enjoyed in the experience of resurrection out of death ([link]vv. 9-10[/link]). This is the gift of grace, which is different from the gifts of abilities mentioned in [link]1 Cor. 12[/link] and [link book="1 Cor."]14[/link]. The gift of grace is inward for life, and the gifts of abilities are outward for function.
Lit., faces; implying that thanks are given by cheerful countenances.

verse.text: For our boasting is this, the testimony of our [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]conscience, that in [note]2[/note]singleness and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]sincerity of God, not in [note]4[/note]fleshly [xref]c[/xref]wisdom but in the [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]grace of God, we have conducted ourselves in the world, and more abundantly toward you.
verse.note: We must have a pure conscience ([link]2 Tim. 1:3[/link]), a conscience without offense ([link]Acts 24:16[/link]), that can bear a testimony to what we are and do.

Or, simplicity. Some MSS read, holiness. The apostles' situation of death forced them to be simple, that is, not to base their confidence on themselves or on their natural human ability to work out a solution to their difficult situation. This was the testimony of their conscience and was their confidence ([link]v. 15[/link]).

A divine virtue, a virtue of what God is. To conduct ourselves in such a virtue means to experience God Himself. Hence, to conduct ourselves in such a virtue is to be in the grace of God (later in the verse).
I.e., human wisdom in the flesh. This equals ourselves, just as the grace of God equals God Himself.

God for our enjoyment (see note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]). Grace here is the gift in [link]v. 11[/link], which the apostles received for the experience of resurrection in their sufferings.

verse.text: For no other things do we write to you than what you read or even know; and I hope that you will know unto the end,
Even as also you know us [xref]a[/xref]in part, that we are your [xref]b[/xref]boast, just as you also are [xref]c[/xref]ours in the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]day of our Lord Jesus.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 3[/link].

verse.text: And in this confidence I intended to [xref]a[/xref]come to you previously that you might have [note]1[/note]double [xref]b[/xref]grace,
verse.note: Lit., second; referring to the double grace bestowed by the apostle's coming to Corinth twice, once in this verse and again in the next verse. Through the apostle's coming, the grace of God, that is, the imparting of God as the life supply and spiritual enjoyment, was bestowed on the believers. His two comings would bring them a double portion of such grace.

verse.text: And through you to pass through into [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Macedonia, and again from Macedonia to come to you and be sent forward by you into [xref]b[/xref]Judea.
verse.note: A province of the Roman Empire, north of Achaia. The cities of Philippi and Thessalonica were in Macedonia.

verse.text: This therefore intending, did I then use fickleness? Or the things which I purpose, do I purpose [xref]a[/xref]according to the flesh, so that with me there should be Yes, yes and No, no?
[note]1[/note]But as God is [xref]a[/xref]faithful, our [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]word toward you is not yes and no.
verse.note: [i]But[/i] gives a contrast. In the preceding verse the apostle referred to the charge that he was a man of yes and no. In this verse he defended himself by saying that because God is faithful, the word of their preaching was not yes and no. Hence, they were not fickle persons of yes and no. Their being was according to their preaching. They lived according to what they preached.
The word of the apostles' preaching ([link]1 Cor. 1:18[/link]), their message concerning Christ ([link]v. 19[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, who was preached among you through us, through me and [note]2[/note]Silvanus and Timothy, did not become yes and no, but [i]our word[/i] has become [xref]a[/xref]yes in Him.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] introduces the reason for what is mentioned in the preceding verse. God is faithful, never changing, especially in His promises concerning Christ. Hence, the word the apostles preached concerning Christ was likewise never changing, because the very Christ whom God promised in His faithful word and whom they preached in their gospel did not become yes and no. Rather, in Him is yes. Since the Christ whom they preached according to God's promises did not become yes and no, the word they preached concerning Him was not yes and no. Not only their preaching but also their living was according to what Christ is. They preached Christ and lived Him. They were not men of yes and no but men who were the same as Christ.
I.e., Silas. See [link]Acts 15:22[/link]; [link]18:5[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For as many [xref]a[/xref]promises of God as [i]there are,[/i] in [note]2[/note]Him is the [note]3[/note]Yes; therefore also through [note]2[/note]Him is [note]4[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]Amen to God, [note]5[/note]for [xref]c[/xref]glory through [note]6[/note]us [i]to God.[/i]
verse.note: Again, [i]for[/i] introduces the reason for what is mentioned in the preceding verse. Christ, whom the faithful God promised and whom the sincere apostles preached, did not become yes and no, did not change, because in Him is the Yes of all the promises of God, and through Him is the apostles' and the believers' Amen to God for His glory.
Christ.
Christ is the Yes, the incarnate answer, the fulfillment of all the promises of God to us.
The Amen given by us through Christ to God (cf. [link]1 Cor. 14:16[/link]). Christ is the Yes, and we say Amen to this Yes before God.
When we say Amen before God to the fact that Christ is the Yes, the fulfillment, of all the promises of God, God is glorified through us.

Referring not only to the apostles, who preached Christ according to God's promises, but also to the believers, who received Christ according to the apostles' preaching. Through us there is glory unto God when we say Amen to Christ as the great Yes of all God's promises.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But the One who [note]2[/note]firmly attaches [note]3[/note]us [note]4[/note]with you unto [note]5[/note]Christ and has [note]6[/note][xref]a[/xref]anointed us is God,
verse.note: The apostles, who preached Christ according to God's promises and lived Christ according to their preaching, and the believers, who received Christ according to the apostles' preaching, are joined to Christ, becoming one with Him, through whom they say Amen before God to the great Yes of God's promises, which is Christ Himself. But it is not they but God who attaches them all together unto Christ. Their being one with Christ is of God and by God, not of themselves and by themselves.

Lit., establishes. God establishes the apostles with the believers in Christ. This means that God firmly attaches the apostles together with the believers unto Christ, the anointed One. Hence, the apostles and the believers are one not only with Christ, the anointed One, but also with one another, sharing the anointing that Christ has received of God.

I.e., the apostles with the believers have been attached to Christ, the anointed One. This shows that the apostles ranked themselves with the believers in being attached to Christ by the anointing Spirit, not considering themselves a special group separate from the believers in God's all-inclusive salvation.
I.e., together with.
I.e., the anointed One ([link]Dan. 9:26[/link], lit.).
Since we have been attached by God to Christ, the anointed One, we are spontaneously anointed with Him by God.

verse.text: He who has also [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sealed us and given the Spirit in our [note]2[/note]hearts as a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]pledge.
verse.note: The anointing in the preceding verse is the sealing. Since God has anointed us with Christ, He has also sealed us in Him. See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link].

The Spirit, the earnest of God as our portion, is a foretaste to us; thus, here it says that He is in our hearts. [link]Romans 5:5[/link] and [link]Gal. 4:6[/link] refer to the matter of love and, hence, speak of the Spirit in our heart. But [link]Rom. 8:16[/link] refers to the work of the Spirit, since it says that the Spirit witnesses with our spirit. Our heart is a loving organ, but our spirit is a working one.

The seal is a mark that marks us out as God's inheritance, God's possession, as those who belong to God. The pledge is an earnest, guaranteeing that God is our inheritance, or possession, and belongs to us (see note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link]). The Spirit within us is the pledge, an earnest, of God as our portion in Christ.[br][br]God's attaching us to Christ issues in three things: (1) an anointing that imparts God's elements into us; (2) a sealing that forms the divine elements into an impression to express God's image; and (3) a pledging that gives us a foretaste as a sample and guarantee of the full taste of God. Through these three experiences of the anointing Spirit, with the experience of the cross, the ministry of Christ is produced.

verse.text: But I call on God as a [xref]a[/xref]witness [note]1[/note]against my [xref]b[/xref]soul that to [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]spare you I have not yet [xref]d[/xref]come to Corinth.
verse.note: Lit., upon. The apostle called on, or asked, God to be a witness against his soul, that is, against himself, should he speak falsely.

The apostle would not come to visit the Corinthian believers with a rod for discipline, but in love and a spirit of meekness for building ([link]1 Cor. 4:21[/link]). In order to avoid any unpleasant feeling, he refrained from coming. He treated them leniently and would not come to them in sorrow ([link]2:1[/link]). He did not like to lord it over their faith but wished to be a fellow worker with them for their joy ([link]v. 24[/link]). This was the truth. He called on God to witness to this for him.

verse.text: Not that we [xref]a[/xref]lord it over your faith, but we are fellow workers with [i]you[/i] for your joy; for by [note]1[/note]faith you [xref]b[/xref]stand.
verse.note: For the believers to stand in the objective faith ([link]1 Cor. 16:13[/link] and note 2), subjective faith is needed. Lording it over their subjective faith weakens it, but being a fellow worker with them for their joy strengthens it.

verse.text: But I [note]1[/note]determined this for myself, that I would not [xref]a[/xref]come again to you in [xref]b[/xref]sorrow.
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]judged.[/i]

verse.text: For if I cause you sorrow, who then is the one who makes me glad, except the one who is made sorrowful by me?

And I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wrote this very thing [i]to you[/i] that when I come I would [xref]b[/xref]not have sorrow from those who ought to make me rejoice, having [xref]c[/xref]confidence in you all that my joy is [i]the joy[/i] of you all.
verse.note: In the first Epistle.

verse.text: For out of much affliction and anguish of heart I [xref]a[/xref]wrote to you through many [xref]b[/xref]tears, not that you would be made sorrowful but that you would know the [xref]c[/xref]love which I have more abundantly toward you.
But if anyone has caused [xref]a[/xref]sorrow, he has not caused me to sorrow, but [xref]b[/xref]in part (lest I [note]1[/note]lay [i]too heavy[/i] a burden) all of you.
verse.note: I.e., apply pressure too heavily, press too heavily, say too much. The apostle said here that the offender caused in part all the church to sorrow. He said "in part" lest he press too heavily, lest he say too much. This indicates that he was a tender, cautious, and considerate person.

verse.text: Sufficient for such a one is this [xref]a[/xref]punishment by the majority,
So that on the contrary you should rather [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forgive and comfort [i]him,[/i] lest perhaps such a one be swallowed up with excessive sorrow.
verse.note: Or, deal graciously with.

verse.text: Therefore I exhort you to [note]1[/note]confirm [i]your[/i] [xref]a[/xref]love toward him.
verse.note: I.e., formally prove by sure evidence.

verse.text: For to this end also I [xref]a[/xref]wrote, that I might [note]1[/note]know your [note]2[/note]approvedness, whether you are [xref]b[/xref]obedient in all things.
verse.note: [i]Know your approvedness[/i] means [i]put you to the test.[/i]
Or, tested character.

verse.text: But whom you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forgive anything, I also [note]1[/note][i]forgive;[/i] for also what I have [note]2[/note]forgiven, if I have [note]2[/note]forgiven anything, [i]it is[/i] for your sake in the [note]3[/note]person of Christ;
verse.note: Or, deal graciously with.
Or, dealt graciously with.

Lit., face; as in [link]4:6[/link]. The part around the eyes; the look as the index of the inward thoughts and feelings, which shows forth and manifests the whole person. This indicates that the apostle was one who lived and acted in the presence of Christ, according to the index of His whole person, expressed in His eyes. The first section, [link]1:1-2:11[/link], is a long introduction to this Epistle, which follows the apostle's first Epistle to the disorderly believers in Corinth. After receiving information that they had repented ([link]7:6-13[/link]) through their accepting of his rebukes in the first Epistle, he was comforted and encouraged. Thus, he wrote this Epistle to comfort and encourage them in a very personal, tender, and affectionate way, in such a way that this Epistle can be considered to some extent his autobiography. In it we see a person who lived Christ according to what he wrote concerning Him in his first Epistle, in the closest and most intimate contact with Him, acting according to the index of His eyes; a person who was one with Christ, full of Christ, and saturated with Christ; a person who was broken and even terminated in his natural life, softened and flexible in his will, affectionate yet restricted in his emotion, considerate and sober in his mind, and pure and genuine in his spirit toward the believers for their benefit, that they might experience and enjoy Christ as he did for the fulfillment of God's eternal purpose in the building up of Christ's Body.

verse.text: That we may not be taken advantage of by [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Satan, for we are not [xref]b[/xref]ignorant of his [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]schemes.
verse.note: This discloses that the evil one, Satan, is behind the scenes in everything and works in everything.
I.e., plans, plots, devices, designs, wiles, intentions, purposes.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Furthermore, when I came to [xref]a[/xref]Troas for the gospel of Christ and a [xref]b[/xref]door was open to me [note]2[/note]in the Lord,
verse.note: In addition to what he mentioned in [link]vv. 10-11[/link], the apostle also told the Corinthian believers of his concern for them. Although in Troas a door had been opened to him, even in the Lord, he had no rest in his spirit when he did not find Titus, whom he was anxious to meet to gain information concerning the effect of his first Epistle among the Corinthians. Then he left Troas and went forth to Macedonia ([link]v. 13[/link]), being anxious to meet Titus to obtain the information. This showed his great affection for the Corinthians. His concern for the church was much greater than his concern for the preaching of the gospel.
Or, by the Lord; i.e., not by human effort.

verse.text: I had no rest in my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit, for I did not find [xref]b[/xref]Titus my brother; but taking leave of them, I went forth into [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Macedonia.
verse.note: This indicates that the apostle was one who lived and acted in his spirit, as indicated in [link]1 Cor. 16:18[/link].
This Epistle was written in Macedonia after Paul's stay in Ephesus on the third journey of his ministry ([link]8:1[/link]; [link]Acts 20:1[/link]).

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]thanks be to God, who always [note]1[/note]leads [note]2[/note]us in [xref]b[/xref]triumph in [note]3[/note]the Christ and manifests the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]savor of the [xref]d[/xref]knowledge of Him through [note]5[/note]us in every place.
verse.note: "The verb here used...means [i]to lead a man as a captive in a triumphal procession;[/i] the full phrase means [i]to lead captive in a triumph over the enemies of Christ.[/i]...God is celebrating His triumph over His enemies; Paul (who had been so great an opponent of the gospel) is a captive following in the train of the triumphal procession, yet (at the same time, by a characteristic change of metaphor) an incense-bearer, scattering incense (which was always done on these occasions) as the procession moves on. Some of the conquered enemies were put to death when the procession reached the Capitol; to them the smell of the incense was 'an odor of death unto death'; to the rest who were spared, 'an odor of life unto life'" (Conybeare). (The same metaphor is used in [link]Col. 2:15[/link].) God always leads the apostles in such a triumphant way for their ministry.[br][br]In the second section of this Epistle, [link]2:12-7:16[/link], the apostle spoke about his and his co-workers' ministry. He first likened their ministry to a celebration of Christ's victory. Their move in their ministry for Christ was like a triumphal procession going from one place to another under God's leading. He and his co-workers were Christ's captives, bearing the fragrant incense of Christ, for His triumphant glory. They had been conquered by Christ and had become His captives in the train of His triumph, scattering the fragrance of Christ from place to place. This was their ministry for Him.

As conquered and captured captives in the train of Christ's triumph, celebrating and participating in Christ's triumph. The apostles were such captives; their move as captives of Christ in their ministry for Him was God's celebration of Christ's victory over His enemies.
See note [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

"According to the Greek usage, [i]savor[/i] and [i]knowledge[/i] are in apposition, so that the knowledge of Christ is symbolized as an odor communicating its nature and efficacy through the apostle's work" (Vincent).

As incense-bearers, scattering the savor of the knowledge of Christ in His triumphant ministry as in a triumphal procession. The apostles were incense-bearers in the ministry of Christ as well as captives in the train of His triumph.

verse.text: For we [note]1[/note]are a [xref]a[/xref]fragrance of Christ to God in those who are being [xref]b[/xref]saved and in those who are [xref]c[/xref]perishing:
verse.note: The apostles, being permeated with Christ, became a fragrance of Christ. They were not merely a sweet savor produced by Christ, but Christ Himself was the savor being exhaled in their life and work to God, both in those who were being saved, as a savor out of life unto life, and in those who were perishing, as a savor out of death unto death.

verse.text: To some a [xref]a[/xref]savor out of death [note]1[/note]unto [xref]b[/xref]death, and to the others a savor out of life [note]1[/note]unto [xref]c[/xref]life. And who is [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]sufficient for these things?
verse.note: I.e., resulting in death...resulting in life. Referring to the effect of the apostles' ministry in two different aspects on different persons. It is a matter of life and death! Only the captives of God in Christ, who are saturated with Christ by the Spirit, are sufficient and qualified for this ([link]3:5-6[/link]).
Or, competent, qualified, fit, worthy. The same Greek word as in [link]3:5[/link].

verse.text: For we are not like the many, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]adulterating the word of God for profit; but as out of [xref]b[/xref]sincerity, but as out of God, before God we [note]2[/note]speak in Christ.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]retailing, hawking.[/i] Originally, it referred to the selling of inferior items at high prices in a tricky way by peddlers who were of low class. Many engaged in this kind of hawking, adulterating the word of God for their profit, but the apostles did not. Out of sincerity and out of God in their ministry, they spoke in Christ the word of God in the sight of God. How sincere and genuine were the apostles in their ministry!
I.e., minister the word of God.

verse.text: Are we beginning again to [xref]a[/xref]commend ourselves? Or do we need, as some do, [xref]b[/xref]letters of commendation to you or from you?
You are [note]1[/note]our [xref]a[/xref]letter, inscribed in [note]2[/note]our hearts, known and read by all men,
verse.note: The believers were the fruit of the apostles' labor, commending the apostles and their ministry to others. Thus, they became the apostles' living letter of commendation, written by the apostles with the indwelling Christ as the content in every part of their inner being.

The Corinthian believers, as the apostles' living letter of commendation, were inscribed in the apostles' hearts; thus, they were carried by the apostles and could not possibly be severed from the apostles. They were in the apostles' hearts ([link]7:3[/link]), brought by them everywhere as their living commendation.

verse.text: Since you are being manifested that you are a [note]1[/note]letter of Christ [note]2[/note]ministered by us, inscribed not with ink but [note]3[/note]with the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit of the [xref]b[/xref]living God; not in [xref]c[/xref]tablets of stone but in tablets of [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]hearts of flesh.
verse.note: A letter of Christ is written with Christ as the content to convey and express Christ. All Christ's believers should be such a living letter of Christ, that others may read and know Christ in their beings.

I.e., written by the ministry of the apostles. The apostles were filled with Christ, so that their ministry spontaneously ministered Christ to those whom they contacted, inscribing Christ in their hearts and making them living letters that conveyed Christ. That the letters were inscribed both in the apostles' hearts ([link]v. 2[/link]) and in the believers' hearts ([link]v. 3[/link]) shows that the proper new covenant ministry, described in this book, always writes something both in the hearts of those who receive the ministry and in the hearts of those who minister. This kind of ministry is in the way of life, with the life-giving Spirit as the essence of the writing (see [link]v. 6[/link] and note [link]3[sup]3[/sup][/link]).

The Spirit of the living God, who is the living God Himself, is not the instrument, like a pen, but the element, like ink used in writing, with which the apostles minister Christ as the content for the writing of living letters that convey Christ.

Our heart, composed of our conscience (the leading part of our spirit), our mind, our emotion, and our will, is the tablet in which the living letters of Christ are written with the living Spirit of God. This implies that Christ is written into every part of our inner being with the Spirit of the living God to make us His living letters, that He may be expressed and read by others in us.

verse.text: And such [xref]a[/xref]confidence we have through Christ toward God,
Not that we are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sufficient of ourselves to [note]2[/note]account anything as from ourselves; but our [note]3[/note]sufficiency is [xref]b[/xref]from God,
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
Or, reckon, evaluate.

Or, competency, qualification. The living God Himself is the sufficiency, competency, and qualification of the apostles' ministry for God's New Testament economy, which is to dispense Christ into God's chosen people for the building up of Christ's Body.

verse.text: Who has also made us [xref]a[/xref]sufficient as [xref]b[/xref]ministers of a [xref]c[/xref]new covenant, [i]ministers[/i] not of the [note]1[/note]letter but of the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]Spirit; for the [note]3[/note]letter kills, but the [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]Spirit gives life.
verse.note: The written code of the law.

The Spirit of the living God, with whom the apostles ministered Christ into the believers to make them the living letters of Christ ([link]v. 3[/link]). Unlike the Mosaic ministry for the Old Testament, the apostolic ministry for the New Testament is not of dead letters but of the living Spirit, who gives life.

The letter of the law, which only requires of man. It is unable to supply man with life ([link]Gal. 3:21[/link]). Because of man's inability to fulfill the requirements of the law, the law kills man ([link]Rom. 7:9-11[/link]).

The Spirit, the ultimate expression of the processed Triune God, who became a life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), imparts the divine life, even God Himself, into the believers and the apostles, making them ministers of a new covenant, the covenant of life. Hence, their ministry is one constituted with the Triune God of life by His life-giving Spirit.

verse.text: Moreover if the [note]1[/note]ministry of [xref]a[/xref]death, engraved in [xref]b[/xref]stone in letters, came about in [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]glory, so that the sons of Israel were not able to gaze at the face of Moses because of the glory of his face, [i]a glory[/i] which was being done away with,
verse.note: The ministry of the old covenant, a covenant of the dead letter, which kills.
The glory that shone temporarily and only on Moses' face ([link]Exo. 34:29[/link], [link]35[/link]).

verse.text: How shall the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ministry of the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit not be more in [note]2[/note]glory?
verse.note: The apostolic ministry of the new covenant, a covenant of the living Spirit, who gives life.

The glory of God manifested in the face of Christ, which is God Himself shining forever in the hearts of the apostles ([link]4:6[/link]), surpassing the glory of the Mosaic ministry of the old covenant ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: For if there is glory with the ministry of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]condemnation, much more the ministry of [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness [note]3[/note]abounds with glory.
verse.note: The ministry of the old covenant became one of death ([link]v. 7[/link]) because the old covenant brought in condemnation unto death ([link]Rom. 5:13[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]20-21[/link]). Hence, it was also the ministry of condemnation.

The ministry of the new covenant is a ministry of the Spirit who gives life ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]6[/link]), because the new covenant brings in God's righteousness unto life ([link]Rom. 5:18[/link], [link]21[/link]). Hence, it is also the ministry of righteousness, the ministry of justification. The focus of the ministry of the new covenant is thus both the Spirit as the life supply, and righteousness, the living out and genuine expression of Christ (the image of God), who as the Spirit is our life ([link]v. 17[/link]).
The apostolic ministry of the new covenant not only has glory but also abounds with the glory of God, which surpasses the glory of the Mosaic ministry of the old covenant ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: For also that which has been [note]1[/note]glorified [note]2[/note]in this respect [note]3[/note]has not been glorified on account of the surpassing glory.
verse.note: Temporarily in the shining of Moses' face.

I.e., in the fact that the glory of the ministry of the law was a temporary glory shining on Moses' face. In this respect it was being done away with on account of the surpassing glory. Because of the glory of the new covenant ministry (which is the glory of God, even God Himself, manifested in the face of Christ forever, surpassing the temporary glory of the old covenant ministry, which was shining on Moses' face), the temporary glory of the ministry of the law disappeared and no longer exists.
I.e., was being done away with ([link]v. 7[/link]).

verse.text: For if that which was [note]1[/note]being done away with was [note]2[/note]through [xref]a[/xref]glory, much more that which remains is in [xref]b[/xref]glory.
verse.note: I.e., in the process of being abolished through the spreading of the new covenant ministry.

[link]Verses 7-11[/link] show the inferiority of the glory of the Mosaic ministry, the ministry of the law, a ministry of condemnation and death, and the superiority of the apostolic ministry, the ministry of grace, a ministry of righteousness and the Spirit. The former was through glory in a temporary way; the latter remains in glory forever.[br][br]In [link]2:12-17[/link] the apostle spoke of the triumph and effect of the apostolic ministry. In [link]vv. 1-6[/link] of this chapter he spoke of its function and competency, and in [link]vv. 7-11[/link], of its glory and superiority.

verse.text: Therefore since we have such [note]1[/note]hope, we use much [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]boldness,
verse.note: I.e., the hope that the shining glory of the new covenant ministry will remain forever. The apostles' having hope was in contrast to Moses' lacking hope because of the fading glory of his old covenant ministry of the law, which was being done away with ([link]v. 13[/link]).

The Greek word implies speaking. In contrast to Moses, who covered his face with a veil ([link]v. 13[/link]), the apostles had the boldness to speak openly and freely concerning their ministry, not hiding, not dissembling.

verse.text: And [i]are[/i] not like Moses, [i]who[/i] put a [xref]a[/xref]veil on his face so that the sons of Israel would not gaze [note]1[/note]at the end of that which was being done away with.
verse.note: While Moses spoke the word of God to the sons of Israel, he kept his glorified face unveiled. But after speaking, he veiled his face ([link]Exo. 34:29-33[/link]) lest they see the end of his ministry, which was passing away. He did not want them to behold the termination of his ministry of the law, which was being done away with.

verse.text: But their [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thoughts were [xref]b[/xref]hardened; for until the present day the same veil remains at the [xref]c[/xref]reading of the old covenant, [note]2[/note]it not being unveiled [i]to them[/i] that [i]the veil[/i] is being done away with in Christ.
verse.note: "Originally, things which proceed out of the mind....[link]Phil. 4:7[/link]...[link]2 Cor. 2:11[/link]. Hence, derivatively, the minds themselves" (Vincent).

[i]It[/i] refers to the fact that the veil is being done away with in Christ. Since this fact had not been unveiled to the sons of Israel, their thoughts were hardened and their minds were blinded. The veil is being done away with in Christ through the new covenant economy, yet it still remains on their heart when they read the old covenant ([link]v. 15[/link]).

verse.text: Indeed unto this day, whenever [note]1[/note]Moses is read, a veil lies on their heart;
verse.note: Referring to Moses' writings, the Pentateuch ([link]John 5:47[/link]).

verse.text: But whenever [note]1[/note][i]their heart[/i] turns to the Lord, the [xref]a[/xref]veil is taken away.
verse.note: This indicates that when their heart is away from the Lord, the veil lies on their heart. When their heart turns to the Lord, the veil is taken away. Actually, their turned-away heart is the veil. To turn their heart to the Lord is to take away the veil.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the [note]2[/note]Lord is the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit; and where the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]Spirit of the Lord is, there is [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]freedom.
verse.note: Or, furthermore, in addition. When the heart turns to the Lord, the veil is taken away. In addition to this, furthermore, the Lord is the Spirit, who would give us freedom. Since the Lord is the Spirit, when the heart turns to Him, the veil is taken away and the heart is freed from the bondage of the letter of the law.

According to the context of this section, which begins at [link]2:12[/link], [i]the Lord[/i] here must refer to Christ the Lord ([link]2:12[/link], [link]14-15[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]3:3-4[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]16[/link]; [link]4:5[/link]). This then is a strong word in the Bible, telling us emphatically that Christ is the Spirit. "The Lord Christ of [link]v. 16[/link] is the Spirit who pervades and animates the new covenant of which we are ministers ([link]v. 6[/link]), and the ministration of which is with glory ([link]v. 8[/link]). Compare [link]Rom. 8:9-11[/link]; [link]John 14:16[/link], [link]18[/link]" (Vincent). "The Lord of [link]v. 16[/link], is the Spirit... which giveth life, [link]v. 6[/link]: meaning, 'the Lord,' as here spoken of, 'Christ,' 'is the Spirit,' is identical with the Holy Spirit...Christ, here, is the Spirit of Christ" (Alford). "All that transforming and indwelling Spirit is Christ Himself. 'The Lord is the Spirit'" (Williston Walker).

The Spirit, who is the ultimate expression of the Triune God, was not yet in [link]John 7:39[/link], because at that time Jesus had not yet been glorified. He had not yet finished the process that He, as the embodiment of God, had to pass through. After His resurrection, that is, after the finishing of all the processes, such as incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection, that the Triune God had to pass through in man for His redemptive economy, He became a life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]). In the New Testament, this life-giving Spirit is called "the Spirit" ([link]Rom. 8:16[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]26-27[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:2[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]6:8[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:7[/link]; [link]3:22[/link]; [link]14:13[/link]; [link]22:17[/link]), the Spirit who gives us the divine life ([link]v. 6[/link]; [link]John 6:63[/link]) and frees us from the bondage of the law.
The Spirit of the Lord is the Lord Himself, with whom is freedom.
Freedom from the letter of the law under the veil ([link]Gal. 2:4[/link]; [link]5:1[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But [note]2[/note]we all with [note]3[/note]unveiled face, [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]beholding and reflecting like a [note]5[/note][xref]b[/xref]mirror the [note]6[/note][xref]c[/xref]glory of the Lord, are [note]7[/note]being [xref]d[/xref]transformed into the [note]8[/note]same [xref]e[/xref]image [note]9[/note]from glory to [xref]f[/xref]glory, even as [note]10[/note]from the [note]11[/note]Lord Spirit.
verse.note: [i]But[/i] indicates that we believers are different from the children of Israel. They were veiled, but we with unveiled face behold and reflect like a mirror the glory of the Lord and are thus being transformed into the same image as the Lord from glory to glory.

The apostles, who, as the examples and representatives of all believers, are the ministers of Christ. In [link]vv. 8-9[/link] the glory is related to the ministry of the new covenant. Here the glory is related to the apostles, the ministers of the new covenant. This shows that the ministry of the new covenant is not merely an activity carried out by the new covenant ministers; rather, it is what the new covenant ministers are. They are one with their ministry, for the same invisible glory saturates and pervades both their work and their being, so that there is no difference between the two.

In contrast to the veiled mind, the veiled heart ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]). That our face is unveiled means that our heart has turned to the Lord, so that the veil has been taken away, and the Lord as the Spirit has freed us from the bondage, the veiling, of the law, so that there is no more insulation between us and the Lord.
To behold the glory of the Lord is to see the Lord ourselves; to reflect the glory of the Lord is to enable others to see Him through us.
We are like mirrors beholding and reflecting the glory of the Lord. This being the case, our face should be fully unveiled that we may see well and reflect properly.

I.e., the glory of the Lord, the resurrected and ascended One, who as both God and man passed through incarnation, human living on the earth, and crucifixion, entered into resurrection, accomplished full redemption, and became a life-giving Spirit. As the life-giving Spirit, He dwells in us to make Himself and all that He has accomplished, obtained, and attained real to us, that we may be one with Him and be transformed into the same image as the Lord from glory to glory.

When we with unveiled face are beholding and reflecting the glory of the Lord, He infuses us with the elements of what He is and what He has done. Thus we are being transformed metabolically to have His life shape by His life power with His life essence; that is, we are being transfigured, mainly by the renewing of our mind ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]), into His image. [i]Being transformed[/i] indicates that we are in the process of transformation.

The image of the resurrected and glorified Christ. To be transformed into the same image is to be conformed to the resurrected and glorified Christ, to be made the same as He is ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]).
I.e., from one degree of glory to another. This indicates an ongoing process in life in resurrection.
[i]From[/i] indicates that the transformation is proceeding from the Spirit rather than being caused by Him.

[i]The Lord Spirit[/i] may be considered a compound title like [i]the Father God[/i] and [i]the Lord Christ.[/i] Again, this expression strongly proves and confirms that the Lord Christ is the Spirit and the Spirit is the Lord Christ. In this chapter, this Spirit is revealed as the inscribing Spirit ([link]v. 3[/link]), the Spirit who gives life ([link]v. 6[/link]), the ministering Spirit ([link]v. 8[/link]), the freeing Spirit ([link]v. 17[/link]), and the transforming Spirit ([link]v. 18[/link]). Such an all-inclusive Spirit is crucial to the ministers of Christ and to their ministry for God's new covenant economy.[br][br]After speaking about the ministry of the new covenant, the apostle spoke about the ministers of the new covenant. From [link]v. 12[/link] through [link]v. 18[/link] he depicted the new covenant ministers as persons whose hearts have turned to the Lord, whose faces are unveiled, who are enjoying the Lord as the Spirit, freeing them from the bondage of the law, and who are being transformed into the image of the Lord by beholding and reflecting Him. Through such a process of transformation they are constituted ministers of Christ by the Spirit with the elements of Christ's person and work. Hence, their person is constituted of and with Christ, and their ministry is to minister Christ to others, infusing them with the all-inclusive Christ as the indwelling, life-giving Spirit. All believers should imitate such ministers to be the same kind of person and to accomplish the same kind of ministry.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore having [note]2[/note]this [xref]a[/xref]ministry as we have been shown [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]mercy, we do [xref]c[/xref]not lose heart;
verse.note: In [link]3:12-18[/link] the apostle depicted how the ministers of the new covenant are constituted. In this chapter, from [link]v. 1[/link] through [link]v. 6[/link] he went on to tell how they as the ministers of the new covenant conducted themselves for the carrying out of their ministry; from [link]v. 7[/link] through [link]v. 18[/link] he described the kind of life they lived, a life that made them one with their ministry. This chapter mentions several aspects of their experience that correspond with and confirm what was spoken in [link]ch. 3[/link] concerning the ministry of the new covenant: (1) the peace the apostle experienced as a result of the manifestation of life in the midst of turmoil in [link]vv. 8-9[/link] corresponds with the righteousness as the fruit of peace ([link]James 3:18[/link]), i.e., the expression of the image of God in a proper and orderly way, mentioned in [link]3:9[/link]; (2) the life in [link]vv. 10-12[/link] corresponds with the Spirit in [link]3:6[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]17-18[/link]; (3) being renewed in [link]v. 16[/link] corresponds with being transformed in [link]3:18[/link]; and (4) the eternal weight of glory in [link]v. 17[/link] corresponds with the degrees of glory in [link]3:18[/link].

The ministry described in [link]2:12-3:18[/link], that is, the unique ministry common to all the apostles of Christ. Although they are many, they have only one ministry — the ministry of the new covenant for the accomplishing of God's New Testament economy. All the apostles' works are to carry out this unique ministry, the ministering of Christ to people for the building up of His Body.
See note [link]13[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Tim. 1[/link].

verse.text: But we have renounced the hidden things of [xref]a[/xref]shame, not walking in [xref]b[/xref]craftiness nor [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]adulterating the word of God, but by the manifestation of the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]truth [xref]e[/xref]commending ourselves to every [xref]f[/xref]conscience of men before God.
verse.note: The original meaning of the Greek word was [i]to ensnare;[/i] later, [i]to corrupt,[/i] as in the adulterating of gold or wine. The meaning is narrower than [i]adulterating[/i] in [link]2:17[/link], which adds the sense [i]for gain's sake.[/i]

[i]The truth[/i] is another expression for the word of God ([link]John 17:17[/link] and notes). It means [i]the reality,[/i] denoting all the real things revealed in God's word, which are mainly Christ as the reality of all the things of God. The manifestation of the truth refers to the apostles' living of Christ. When they lived Christ, who is the truth ([link]John 14:6[/link]), they manifested the truth. As Christ was lived out of them, the truth was manifested in them. By this, they commended themselves to every conscience of men before God. The apostles behaved themselves not in the way of adulterating the word of God but in the way of manifesting the truth for the shining of the gospel of the glory of Christ, by the excellent power of the priceless treasure, the very Christ who entered into them and became their content ([link]v. 7[/link]) through the enlightenment of God's shining ([link]v. 6[/link]).

verse.text: And even if our gospel is [note]1[/note]veiled, it is [xref]a[/xref]veiled in those who are [xref]b[/xref]perishing,
verse.note: Veiled by old concepts, especially the concept concerning the law ([link]3:14-15[/link]). In principle, anything such as philosophy, religion, or cultural traditions that hinders people from apprehending the gospel of Christ is a veil. Hence, the preaching of Christ must unveil them, just as in photography the cover is removed from the lens that it might take in the view.

verse.text: In whom the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]god of [xref]b[/xref]this age has [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]blinded the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]thoughts of the unbelievers that the [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]illumination of the gospel of the [xref]f[/xref]glory of Christ, who is the [xref]g[/xref]image of God, might not [note]5[/note]shine [i]on them.[/i]
verse.note: Satan, the deceiver, the ruler of the present age, who dominates today's world and hunts for man's worship by blinding his mind and his thoughts.
I.e., has veiled men's understanding.
Or, minds. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

Christ as the image of God is the effulgence of His glory ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]). Hence, the gospel of Christ is the gospel of His glory that illuminates and shines forth. Satan, the god of this age, has blinded the thoughts and the minds of the unbelievers so that the illumination of the gospel of Christ's glory might not shine into their hearts. This is similar to a camera lens's being covered so that the light cannot shine into the camera to bring in the image. It is also like a blind man, or a man with his eyes veiled, into whom the light of the sun is unable to shine.
The Greek word means (1) [i]to[/i] see distinctly, [i]to discern,[/i] and (2) [i]to shine.[/i]

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For we do not [xref]a[/xref]preach ourselves but Christ Jesus as [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Lord, and ourselves as your [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]slaves for Jesus' sake.
verse.note: This explains why the apostles' gospel, which is the gospel of the glory of Christ, should not have been veiled: they did not preach, exalt, themselves but Christ Jesus as Lord of all, and they conducted themselves as the believers' slaves for Jesus' sake.

Christ Jesus as Lord comprises Christ, who is over all, God blessed forever ([link]Rom. 9:5[/link]), the eternal Word incarnated to be a man ([link]John 1:14[/link]), Jesus crucified as a man to be our Savior ([link]Acts 4:10-12[/link]) and resurrected to be the Son of God ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]), and Christ exalted to be the Lord ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]), even the Lord of all men ([link]Acts 10:36[/link]; [link]Rom. 10:12[/link]; [link]John 20:28[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:3[/link]), who is the image of God, the effulgence of God's glory ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]). This is the very content of the gospel. Hence, the gospel is the gospel of the glory of Christ, which illuminates, radiates, and shines in the heart of man ([link]v. 6[/link]). If man's heart is not veiled with anything or blinded by Satan, the god of this age, man can see the illumination of the gospel ([link]v. 4[/link]).
In contrast to [i]Lord.[/i] The apostles exalted Christ as Lord but considered themselves merely slaves to serve the believers.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Because the God who said, Out of [xref]a[/xref]darkness [xref]b[/xref]light shall shine, is the One who shined [note]2[/note]in [note]3[/note]our [xref]c[/xref]hearts to [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]illuminate the knowledge of the [xref]e[/xref]glory of God in the [note]5[/note]face of Jesus Christ.
verse.note: This explains what is mentioned in the preceding verse. The apostles preached Christ as Lord and themselves as the believers' slaves because the very God who commanded light to shine out of darkness had shined in their hearts. His shining in the universe produced the old creation. Now His shining in their hearts made them a new creation. Therefore, in their preaching they were able to exalt Christ as the Lord, and in their ministry, to conduct themselves as slaves of the believers. What they did for Christ and what they were to the believers were the issue of God's shining. God's shining produces the new covenant ministers and their ministry.

In our hearts is much deeper than on the skin of Moses' face ([link]3:7[/link]; [link]Exo. 34:29-30[/link]). This presents a comparison between the glory of the apostolic ministry of the gospel and that of the Mosaic ministry of the law. In the heart is related to the inner life, whereas on the skin of the face has nothing to do with the inner life. The glory of the old covenant is on the surface, but the glory of the new covenant has great depth.
The apostles' hearts. The apostles represent all the believers of the new covenant.

The illumination here, which refers to the shining of God's light on others out from those whose hearts have been enlightened by God, corresponds with the manifestation in [link]v. 2[/link] and is the same as the shining in [link]Matt. 5:16[/link] and [link]Phil. 2:15[/link]. God shines in our hearts that we may shine on others so that they may have the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ, that is, the knowledge of Christ, who expresses and declares God ([link]John 1:18[/link]).

The face of Jesus Christ is in comparison with the face of Moses ([link]3:7[/link]). The glory of the gospel in the face of Jesus Christ is much superior to the glory of the law in the face of Moses. The former shines in the face of One through whom grace and reality came, issuing in righteousness and the Spirit — life ([link]3:8-9[/link]); the latter shone in the face of one through whom the law was given ([link]John 1:17[/link]), resulting in condemnation and death ([link]3:7[/link], [link]9[/link]). The shining of God in our hearts is to illumine us that we may know not the glory on Moses' face but the glory in Christ's face; it is to enlighten us that we may know not the law of Moses of the old covenant but the gospel of Christ of the new covenant. The glory of God manifested in the face of Jesus Christ is the God of glory expressed through Jesus Christ, and it is Jesus Christ, who is the effulgence of the glory of God ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]); to know Him is to know the God of glory.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But we have this [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]treasure in earthen [xref]b[/xref]vessels that the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]excellency of the [xref]d[/xref]power may be of God and not out of us.
verse.note: God's shining in our hearts brings into us a treasure, the Christ of glory, who is the embodiment of God to be our life and our everything. But we who contain this treasure are earthen vessels, worthless and fragile. A priceless treasure is contained in worthless vessels! This has made the worthless vessels ministers of the new covenant with a priceless ministry. This has been accomplished by the divine power in resurrection. The excellency of the power is surely of God and not out of us.[br][br]In the apostles' speaking concerning their ministry for God's new covenant, five very significant and expressive metaphors were used to illustrate how they, as the ministers of the new covenant, and their ministry were constituted, how they behaved and lived, and how their ministry was carried out:[br][br](1) Captives in a triumphal procession for the celebration of Christ's victory ([link]2:14a[/link]);[br][br](2) Incense-bearers to scatter the fragrance of Christ ([link]2:14b-16[/link]);[br][br](3) Letters written with Christ as the content ([link]3:1-3[/link]);[br][br](4) Mirrors beholding and reflecting the glory of Christ in order to be transformed into His glorious image ([link]3:18[/link]);[br][br](5) Earthen vessels to contain the Christ of glory as the excellent treasure ([link]v. 7[/link]). These vessels are like today's camera, into which Christ the figure enters through the flash of God's shining ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]6[/link]).

This treasure, the indwelling Christ, in us, the earthen vessels, is the divine source of the supply for the Christian life. It is by the excellent power of this treasure that the apostles as the ministers of the new covenant were capable of living a crucified life that the resurrection life of Christ, whom they ministered, might be manifested. Thus, they manifested the truth ([link]v. 2[/link]) for the shining of the gospel.
Or, transcendence, surpassing greatness, exceeding greatness.

verse.text: [i]We are[/i] [note]1[/note]pressed on [xref]a[/xref]every side but not [note]2[/note]constricted; unable to find a way out but not [xref]b[/xref]utterly without a way out;
verse.note: Or, afflicted. The description of their life, from this verse through [link]v. 18[/link], shows that the apostles lived a crucified life in resurrection, or lived the resurrection life under the killing of the cross, for the carrying out of their ministry.
Or, restricted.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Persecuted but not [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]abandoned; [note]3[/note]cast down but [xref]c[/xref]not [note]4[/note]destroyed;
verse.note: Or, pursued (by enemies).
Or, deserted, forsaken; lit., left behind (in some terrible plight).
Or, struck down.
I.e., killed. The same Greek word as for [i]perishing[/i] in [link]v. 3[/link].

verse.text: Always bearing about [xref]a[/xref]in the body the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]putting to [xref]c[/xref]death of Jesus [note]2[/note]that the [note]3[/note]life of Jesus also may be manifested in our body.
verse.note: I.e., the killing, the deadening; referring to the working of death, the working of the cross, which the Lord Jesus suffered and went through. In our experience this is a kind of suffering, persecution, or dealing that comes upon us for the sake of Jesus, for the sake of the Body of Christ, and for the sake of the new covenant ministry. This does not refer to sufferings and troubles that are common to all human beings in the old creation, such as illness or calamity, or to punishment, correction, or discipline suffered because of sins, mistakes, or failure to fulfill one's responsibility. This putting to death of Jesus consumes our natural man, our outward man, our flesh, so that our inward man may have the opportunity to develop and be renewed ([link]v. 16[/link]).
In order that, with the result that. The killing of the cross results in the manifestation of the resurrection life. This daily killing is for the release of the divine life in resurrection.
The resurrection life, which the Lord Jesus lived and expressed through the working of the cross.

verse.text: For we who are alive are always being delivered unto [xref]a[/xref]death for Jesus' sake that the [xref]b[/xref]life of [note]1[/note]Jesus also may be manifested in our [xref]c[/xref]mortal [note]2[/note]flesh.
verse.note: The title [i]Jesus[/i] in these two verses implies that the apostles lived a life like the one the Lord Jesus lived on earth. The Lord's life was a life under the killing of the cross for the manifestation of the resurrection life, a life lived in such a way that His person was one with His ministry and His life was His ministry ([link]John 6:14-15[/link]; [link]12:13[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]23-24[/link]).
The use of [i]flesh[/i] and [i]body[/i] interchangeably in [link]vv. 10[/link] and [link]11[/link] indicates that our mortal flesh is our fallen body.

verse.text: So then [xref]a[/xref]death operates in us, but [note]1[/note]life in you.
verse.note: When we are under the killing of the Lord's death, His resurrection life is imparted through us into others. The impartation of life into others is always the issue of our suffering the killing of the cross.

verse.text: And having the [note]1[/note]same [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit of [xref]b[/xref]faith according to that which is written, [xref]c[/xref]"I believed, therefore I spoke," we also believe, therefore we also speak,
verse.note: The same spirit as set forth in the words quoted later in this verse.

"Not distinctly the Holy Spirit, — but still not merely a human disposition: the indwelling Holy Spirit penetrates and characterizes the whole renewed man" (Alford). "Spirit of faith: not distinctly the Holy Spirit, nor, on the other hand, a human faculty or disposition, but blending both" (Vincent). The spirit of faith is the Holy Spirit mingled with our human spirit. We must exercise such a spirit to believe and to speak, like the psalmist, the things we have experienced of the Lord, especially His death and resurrection. Faith is in our spirit, which is mingled with the Holy Spirit, not in our mind. Doubts are in our mind. Here [i]spirit[/i] indicates that it is by the mingled spirit that the apostles lived a crucified life in resurrection for the carrying out of their ministry.

verse.text: Knowing that He who [xref]a[/xref]raised the Lord Jesus will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]raise us also with Jesus and will [xref]c[/xref]make [i]us[/i] stand before [i]Him[/i] with you.
verse.note: This indicates that the apostles considered themselves dead persons ([link]1:9[/link]), for they were always being delivered unto death for the Lord's purpose ([link]v. 11[/link]).

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]all things are [xref]b[/xref]for your sakes that the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]grace which has abounded through the greater number may cause the [xref]d[/xref]thanksgiving to abound to the [xref]e[/xref]glory of God.
verse.note: Grace, according to the context, is the very Christ, who lived in the apostles as their life and life supply for them to live a crucified life for the manifestation of the resurrection life that they might carry out their ministry for God's new covenant. See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link].

verse.text: Therefore we do [xref]a[/xref]not lose heart; but though our [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]outer man is [note]2[/note]decaying, yet our [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]inner [i]man[/i] is being [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]renewed day by day.
verse.note: The outer man consists of the body as its organ with the soul as its life and person. The inner man consists of the regenerated spirit as its life and person with the renewed soul as its organ. The life of the soul must be denied ([link]Matt. 16:24-25[/link]), but the faculties of the soul — the mind, will, and emotion — must be renewed and uplifted by being subdued ([link]10:4-5[/link]) so that they can be used by the spirit, the person of the inner man.

Or, being consumed, being wasted away, being worn out. By the continued killing, the working of death, our outer man, that is, our material body with its animating soul ([link]1 Cor. 15:44[/link] and note), is being consumed and worn out.

By being nourished with the fresh supply of the resurrection life. As our mortal body, our outer man, is being consumed by the killing work of death, our inner man, that is, our regenerated spirit with the inward parts of our being ([link]Jer. 31:33[/link]; [link]Heb. 8:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 7:22[/link], [link]25[/link]), is being metabolically renewed day by day with the supply of the resurrection life.

verse.text: For our [xref]a[/xref]momentary lightness of [note]1[/note]affliction works out for us, [note]2[/note]more and more surpassingly, an [note]3[/note]eternal weight of [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]glory,
verse.note: Referring to the putting to death, the working of the cross ([link]v. 10[/link]).
Lit., excessively unto excess.
In contrast to momentary lightness.
The expression of God as resurrection life. Glory is in contrast to affliction.

verse.text: Because we do not regard the [note]1[/note]things which are [xref]a[/xref]seen but the [note]2[/note]things which are [xref]b[/xref]not seen; for the things which are seen are temporary, but the things which are not seen are [xref]c[/xref]eternal.
verse.note: Things of the temporary affliction.
Things of the eternal glory.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For we know that if our [note]2[/note]earthly [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]tabernacle dwelling is taken down, we have a [note]4[/note]building [note]5[/note]from God, a [note]6[/note]dwelling [xref]b[/xref]not made with hands, [xref]c[/xref]eternal, [note]7[/note][xref]d[/xref]in the heavens.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that what is to be mentioned is an explanation of what was spoken in [link]4:13-18[/link]. In this chapter the apostle tells us of the apostles' aspiration for the redemption of their bodies ([link]vv. 1-8[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:23[/link]), their ambition, their determination, to please the Lord ([link]vv. 9-15[/link]), and their commission from the Lord for His new creation ([link]vv. 16-21[/link]).
Not made of earth but on the earth.
I.e., our physical body, in which our person dwells and which is not only for our living but also for our worshipping God (cf. [link]1 Cor. 6:19[/link]).

A building with a foundation, in contrast to the tabernacle, which had no foundation. This building is our resurrected, transfigured body, the spiritual body mentioned in [link]1 Cor. 15[/link], and is in contrast to the dying, physical, natural body that we have today.
Lit., out of.
Our spiritual body ([link]1 Cor. 15:44[/link]).
In contrast to [i]earthly,[/i] i.e., on the earth.

verse.text: For also in [note]1[/note]this we [xref]a[/xref]groan, longing to be [note]2[/note]clothed upon with our [note]3[/note]dwelling place [note]4[/note]from heaven,
verse.note: Referring to [i]tabernacle[/i] in [link]v. 1[/link].
I.e., to have our body transfigured and conformed to the body of Christ's glory. The apostles were longing for this.
Referring to the dwelling in the heavens in the preceding verse.
Lit., out of.

verse.text: If indeed, being clothed, we will not be found [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]naked.
verse.note: I.e., without a body. A dead person, being disembodied, is naked, without a body as a covering before God. The apostles were expecting to be transfigured in their bodies, to be clothed with a spiritual body to meet the Lord before they died and were disembodied, that they might not be found naked.

verse.text: For also, we who are in this tabernacle groan, being [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]burdened, [note]2[/note]in that we do not desire to be unclothed, but clothed upon, that [note]3[/note]what is [xref]b[/xref]mortal may be [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]swallowed up by life.
verse.note: I.e., Weighed down, depressed, oppressed.

The apostles groaned in the desire not to be unclothed, disembodied, that is, in the desire not to die but to be clothed, to put on the spiritual body, that is, to have their body transfigured ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]), to have their body redeemed ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]).
Our mortal body ([link]4:11[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:11[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:53[/link]).
The death in our mortal body is swallowed up by resurrection life. Through this our body will be transfigured ([link]1 Cor. 15:54[/link]).

verse.text: Now He who has [note]1[/note]wrought us for this very thing is God, who has given to us the Spirit as a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]pledge.
verse.note: Or, fashioned, shaped, prepared, made fit. God has wrought us, fashioned us, shaped us, prepared us, made us fit, for the very purpose that our mortal body might be swallowed up by His resurrection life. Thus our entire being will be saturated with Christ. God has given us the Spirit as the pledge, the earnest, the foretaste, the guarantee, of this wonderful and marvelous part of His complete salvation, which He has prepared for us in Christ.
See note [link]22[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Therefore being always of good courage and knowing that while we are [note]1[/note]at home in the body, we are [note]1[/note]abroad from the Lord
verse.note: Our body is in the material realm; the Lord is in the spiritual realm. In this sense we are abroad from the Lord when we are at home in our body.

verse.text: (For we [note]1[/note]walk by [xref]a[/xref]faith, not by [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]appearance) —
verse.note: The apostles regulated their lives and conducted themselves by faith, as mentioned in [link]Heb. 11[/link], not by that which was seen. It was in this way that they realized they were away from the Lord while they were in their physical body. This corresponds with the word in [link]4:18[/link].
I.e., that which is seen; hence, sight.

verse.text: We are of good courage then and are well pleased rather [note]1[/note]to be [xref]a[/xref]abroad from the body and at home with the Lord.
verse.note: I.e., to die, thus being released from the material realm to be with the Lord in the spiritual realm. The apostles, who were always being persecuted unto death ([link]1:8-9[/link]; [link]4:11[/link]; [link]11:23[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:31[/link]), were well pleased rather to die that they might be released from their confining body to be at home with the Lord in a better realm ([link]Phil. 1:23[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore also we are [note]1[/note]determined, whether [note]2[/note]at home or abroad, to gain the honor of being [xref]a[/xref]well pleasing to Him.
verse.note: Zealous with a strong aim, striving earnestly to be well pleasing to the Lord.
I.e., living and thus remaining in the body, or dying and thus being with the Lord.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For we must all be [xref]a[/xref]manifested before the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]judgment seat of Christ, that each one may [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]receive the things [i]done[/i] [note]4[/note]through the body according to what he has practiced, whether good or [note]5[/note]bad.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] points to the reason for the determination mentioned in [link]v. 9[/link].

Where Christ will judge His believers at His coming back, not concerning their eternal salvation but concerning their dispensational reward ([link]1 Cor. 4:4-5[/link]; [link]3:13-15[/link]). See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 14[/link].
"The technical word for receiving wages" (Alford).
While we are still at home in the body, we should do things through it to please the Lord that we may be rewarded by the Lord at His coming.
Or, worthless.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Knowing therefore the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]fear of the Lord, we [note]3[/note]persuade men, but we are made manifest to God; yet I hope that we are made manifest also in your [xref]b[/xref]consciences.
verse.note: I.e., being conscious of fearing the Lord. [i]Therefore[/i] indicates that this consciousness is due to the judgment seat of Christ mentioned in [link]v. 10[/link].
Not the Lord's being fearsome but our fearing the Lord.

The apostles, conscious of fearing the Lord, persuaded men concerning their integrity, concerning what kind of persons they were, toward both God and men. They did not need to persuade God, for what they were had already been made manifest to God; yet, the apostles hoped that they had been made manifest also in the believers' consciences.

verse.text: We are not again [xref]a[/xref]commending ourselves to you, but [i]so speak[/i] in order to give you an opportunity to [xref]b[/xref]boast on our behalf, that you may [note]1[/note]have [i]an answer[/i] for those who are [xref]c[/xref]boasting in [xref]d[/xref]outward [note]2[/note]appearance and not in [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]heart.
verse.note: I.e., have words to answer those who are boasting.
Lit., face. The outward appearance of the Judaizers.
Where the sincerity and reality of the virtues are.

verse.text: For whether we were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]beside ourselves, [i]it was[/i] to God; or whether we are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sober-minded, [i]it is[/i] [xref]c[/xref]for you.
verse.note: I.e., mad, as a fool, for God's glory ([link]Acts 26:24-25[/link]). The apostles' ecstasy was not an excitement out of folly, but it was to God and with God for His glory.
Self-controlled in love for others' good.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love of Christ [note]2[/note]constrains us because we [note]3[/note]have judged this, that [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]One died for all, [note]5[/note]therefore [xref]c[/xref]all died;
verse.note: The love of Christ toward us, which was manifested on the cross through His dying for us ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]).

The Greek word means [i]to press on[/i]...[i]from all sides, to hold[/i]...[i]to one end, to forcibly limit, to confine to one object within certain bounds, to shut up to one line and purpose[/i] (as in a narrow, walled road). (The same Greek word is used in [link]Luke 4:38[/link]; [link]12:50[/link]; [link]Acts 18:5[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:23[/link].) In such a way the apostles were constrained by the love of Christ to live to Him.
I.e., have concluded (probably at the time of conversion).
Christ's loving death is the motivating factor in the apostles' being constrained to live a loving life for Him.

Since Christ died as our Substitute, suffering the sentence of death on behalf of us all, in the eyes of God we all died. Hence, we do not need to die as has been reserved for men ([link]Heb. 9:27[/link]).

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]died for all that those who [xref]b[/xref]live may [note]1[/note]no longer live to themselves but [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]to Him who died for them and has been raised.
verse.note: Christ's death not only saves us from death so that we do not need to die, but also causes us, through His resurrection, to live no longer to ourselves but to Him.

Living to the Lord is deeper in significance than living for the Lord. Living for the Lord implies that I and the Lord are still two; living to the Lord indicates that I am one with the Lord, as the wife is one with the husband in married life.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]So then we, from now on, [note]2[/note]know no one according to the [xref]a[/xref]flesh; even though we have [note]2[/note]known Christ [xref]b[/xref]according to the flesh, yet now we [note]2[/note]know [i]Him so[/i] no longer.
verse.note: Since the apostles judged that Christ's death made us all, through His resurrection, a new man, a man not according to the flesh, they would no longer know anyone according to the flesh. They had known Christ in that way, but now they knew Him so no longer.
The first [i]know[/i] refers to the inward, subjective consciousness; [i]known[/i] and the second [i]know[/i] refer to the outward, objective knowledge. See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 6[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]So then if anyone is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]in Christ, [i]he is[/i] a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]new creation. The [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]old things have [xref]d[/xref]passed away; [note]5[/note]behold, [note]6[/note]they have become [xref]e[/xref]new.
verse.note: This confirms what is mentioned in the preceding verse. The apostles would no longer know anyone according to the flesh, because anyone who is in Christ is a new creation; the old things of the flesh have passed away through the death of Christ, and all has become new in Christ's resurrection.
To be in Christ is to be one with Him in life and nature. This is of God through our faith in Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:26-28[/link]).

The old creation does not have the divine life and nature, but the new creation, constituted of the believers, who are born again of God, does ([link]John 1:13[/link]; [link]3:15[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]). Hence, the believers are a new creation ([link]Gal. 6:15[/link]), not according to the old nature of the flesh but according to the new nature of the divine life.
Or, ancient.
A call to watch the marvelous change of the new creation.
Referring to the old things.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]all things are out from God, who has [xref]a[/xref]reconciled us to Himself through Christ and has given to us the [xref]b[/xref]ministry of reconciliation;
verse.note: Referring to all the positive things mentioned in [link]vv. 14-21[/link], of which God is the Originator and Initiator. It is of God that Christ died to save us from death that we might live to Him. It is of God that we have become a new creation in Christ. It is of God that Christ was made sin for us that we might become God's righteousness in Him. It is of God that He reconciled the world to Himself. And it is of God that the apostles are made ambassadors of Christ, commissioned to represent Him for the reconciling of men to God, that men may become God's righteousness and a new creation for the fulfillment of God's eternal purpose.

verse.text: Namely, that God [xref]a[/xref]in Christ was reconciling the [xref]b[/xref]world to Himself, [xref]c[/xref]not accounting their offenses to them, and has put in us the [note]1[/note]word of reconciliation.
verse.note: The word is for the ministry ([link]v. 18[/link]).

verse.text: On behalf of Christ then we are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ambassadors, as God [xref]b[/xref]entreats [i]you[/i] through us; we beseech [i]you[/i] on behalf of Christ, Be [note]2[/note]reconciled to God.
verse.note: The apostles were commissioned with a definite ministry, to represent Christ to accomplish God's purpose.

In the preceding verse it was the world that was reconciled to God; in this verse it is the believers, who have already been reconciled to God and are to be reconciled further to God. This clearly indicates that two steps are required for men to be fully reconciled to God. The first step is to reconcile sinners to God from sin. For this purpose Christ died for our sins ([link]1 Cor. 15:3[/link]) that they might be forgiven by God. This is the objective aspect of Christ's death.
