In this aspect He bore our sins on the cross that they might be judged by God upon Him for us. The second step is to reconcile believers living in the natural life to God from the flesh. For this purpose Christ died for us — the persons — that we might live to Him in the resurrection life ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]). This is the subjective aspect of Christ's death. In this aspect He was made sin for us to be judged and done away with by God that we might become the righteousness of God in Him. By the two aspects of His death He has fully reconciled God's chosen people to God. These two steps of reconciliation are clearly portrayed by the two veils of the tabernacle. The first veil is called "the screen" ([link]Exo. 26:37[/link]). A sinner who was brought to God through the reconciliation of the propitiating blood entered into the Holy Place by passing this screen. This typifies the first step of reconciliation. The second veil ([link]Exo. 26:31-35[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:3[/link]) still separated him from God, who was in the Holy of Holies. This veil needed to be rent that the sinner might be brought to God in the Holy of Holies. This is the second step of reconciliation. The Corinthian believers had been reconciled to God, having passed through the first veil and having entered into the Holy Place. Yet they still lived in the flesh. They needed to pass the second veil, which had been rent already ([link]Matt. 27:51[/link]; [link]Heb. 10:20[/link]), to enter into the Holy of Holies to live with God in their spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). The goal of this Epistle was to bring them there that they might be persons in the spirit ([link]1 Cor. 2:15[/link]), in the Holy of Holies. This was what the apostle meant by saying, "Be reconciled to God." This was to present them full-grown in Christ ([link]Col. 1:28[/link]).

verse.text: Him who did [note]1[/note]not know sin He made [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]sin on our behalf that we might become the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness of God [note]4[/note]in Him.
verse.note: Christ did not know sin in an experiential way by contact or personal experience (cf. [link]John 8:46[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:22[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]; [link]7:26[/link]).

Sin came from Satan, who rebelled against God ([link]Isa. 14:12-14[/link]). This sin, which came out of the evil one, entered into man ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]) and made man not only a sinner but sin itself under God's judgment. Hence, when Christ became a man in the flesh ([link]John 1:14[/link]), He was made sin (not sinful) on our behalf to be judged by God ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]) that we might become God's righteousness in Him.

Righteousness issues from God for His administration ([link]Psa. 89:14[/link]; [link]97:2[/link]; [link]Isa. 32:1[/link]). This righteousness is Christ to be our righteousness ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]), making us God's righteousness in Him (not making us righteous before God). Through Christ's redemption, man, who is a sinner and is even sin, is made God's righteousness, being reconciled to the righteous God, and is made a new creation living to God for His eternal purpose. The apostles are commissioned to minister such a Christ, with all the glorious issues of His marvelous achievement, to His believers, who are the members that form His Body. Praise and glory be to Him forever!

In union with Him, not only positionally but also organically in resurrection. We were enemies of God ([link]Col. 1:21[/link]) by becoming sin, which came from Satan, who rebelled against God. Christ was made sin for us by becoming one with us through being incarnated in the flesh. Through His death He was condemned in the flesh as sin for us by God that we might be one with Him in His resurrection to be God's righteousness. By this righteousness we, the enemies of God, could be and have been reconciled to God ([link]vv. 18-20[/link]; [link]Rom. 5:10[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And working [note]2[/note]together with [i]Him,[/i] we also [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]entreat you not to receive the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]grace of God in vain;
verse.note: [i]And[/i] here indicates a continuation. In the last part of [link]ch. 5[/link] ([link]5:16-21[/link]) the apostle told us that they, the ministers of the new covenant, had been commissioned with the ministry of reconciliation for the Lord's new creation. From this verse to the end of [link]ch. 7[/link] he continued by telling us how they worked. They worked together with God by a life (not by any gift) that was all-sufficient and all-mature, able to fit all situations, that is, able to endure any kind of treatment, to accept any kind of environment, to work in any kind of condition, and to take any kind of opportunity, for the carrying out of their ministry.
The apostles not only were commissioned by God with their ministry but also were working together with Him. They were God's co-workers ([link]1 Cor. 3:9[/link]).
This is the work of reconciliation, as mentioned in [link]5:20[/link].

See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]. The grace of God always brings us back to Him. Not to receive the grace of God in vain, according to the context, means not to remain in any condition that is a distraction from God, but to be brought back to Him.

verse.text: For He says, [xref]a[/xref]"In an [xref]b[/xref]acceptable time I listened to you, and in the day of salvation I helped you." Behold, now is the [note]1[/note]well-[xref]c[/xref]acceptable time; behold, now is the [xref]d[/xref]day of [note]2[/note]salvation.
verse.note: This refers to the time of our being reconciled to God, when He well accepts us.
Referring to reconciliation, according to the context, which is continued from the end of [link]ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]We give no occasion of stumbling in anything that the [note]2[/note]ministry may not be faulted,
verse.note: From here to the end of [link]ch. 7[/link] the apostle depicted a life that was all-fitting for the carrying out of their ministry.
The ministry of the new covenant ([link]3:8-9[/link]; [link]4:1[/link]).

verse.text: But in everything we [xref]a[/xref]commend ourselves as [xref]b[/xref]ministers of God, in much [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]endurance, in [xref]d[/xref]afflictions, in [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]necessities, in [xref]f[/xref]distresses,
verse.note: Endurance is the first qualification for the all-fitting life of the new covenant ministers. This refers not merely to a kind of patience but to the ability to endure suffering in tribulation, whether pressure, oppression, persecution, poverty, or any kind of trial.
The Greek word denotes constraints, urgent needs that press heavily, indicating a shortage of daily necessities such as food, lodging, or clothing.

verse.text: In [xref]a[/xref]stripes, in [xref]b[/xref]imprisonments, in [xref]c[/xref]tumults, in [xref]d[/xref]labors, in [note]1[/note][xref]e[/xref]watchings, in [note]2[/note]fastings;
verse.note: I.e., sleeplessnesses, as occurred in [link]Acts 16:25[/link]; [link]20:7-11[/link], [link]31[/link]; and [link]2 Thes. 3:8[/link].
Because of the lack of food. See note [link]27[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: In pureness, in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]knowledge, in long-suffering, in kindness, in a [xref]b[/xref]holy [note]2[/note]spirit, in [xref]c[/xref]unfeigned [note]1[/note]love,
verse.note: Knowledge is a matter of the mind; love, a matter of the heart.

Referring to the apostles' regenerated spirit. With stripes on the body ([link]v. 5[/link]), knowledge in the mind, and love in the heart, the entire being of the apostles, including body, soul, and spirit, was exercised in their living for the carrying out of their ministry.

verse.text: In the [xref]a[/xref]word of truth, in the [xref]b[/xref]power of God; through the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]weapons of righteousness [note]2[/note]on the right and on the left,
verse.note: This indicates that the apostles' life for their ministry was a life in the battle, fighting for God's kingdom. Weapons of righteousness are used for fighting that we may be right with God and men according to the righteousness of God ([link]Matt. 6:33[/link]; [link]5:6[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]20[/link]).
Weapons on the right hand, such as the sword, are offensive; those on the left hand, such as the shield, are defensive.

verse.text: Through [note]1[/note]glory and [xref]a[/xref]dishonor, through [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]evil report and good report; as [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]deceivers and yet [xref]d[/xref]true;
verse.note: Glory is from God and those who love Him; dishonor is from the devil and those who follow him.
An evil report comes from the opposers and persecutors ([link]Matt. 5:11[/link]); a good report comes from the believers and those who receive the truth preached and taught by the apostles.
As deceivers in the eyes of the Judaizers and the people of other religions and philosophies, but true in the eyes of those who love the truth of God.

verse.text: As [note]1[/note]unknown and yet well known; as [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]dying and yet behold we [xref]b[/xref]live; as [note]3[/note]being disciplined and yet [xref]c[/xref]not being put to death;
verse.note: As unknown in the sense of not displaying themselves, but well known in the sense of witnessing to the truth of God.
As dying in suffering persecutions ([link]1:8-10[/link]; [link]4:11[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:31[/link]), but living in the Lord's resurrection ([link]4:10-11[/link]).
As being disciplined in the opposers' superficial realization, but not being put to death in the sovereign care of the Lord.

verse.text: As [note]1[/note]made [xref]a[/xref]sorrowful yet always [xref]b[/xref]rejoicing; as [note]2[/note]poor yet [xref]c[/xref]enriching many; as [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]having nothing and yet possessing [xref]e[/xref]all things.
verse.note: As made sorrowful by the negative conditions of the churches ([link]11:28[/link]), yet always rejoicing in the sufficient grace and resurrection life of Christ ([link]12:9-10[/link]).
As poor in material things, yet enriching many in spiritual riches ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]).
As having nothing in a human way, but possessing all things in the divine economy.

verse.text: Our mouth is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]opened to you, Corinthians; our heart is [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]enlarged.
verse.note: The apostles, all-mature and all-fitting, as depicted in [link]vv. 3-10[/link], had their mouths opened and their hearts enlarged to the believers. With an enlarged heart they were able to embrace all believers regardless of their condition, and with an opened mouth they were free to speak to all believers frankly concerning the real situation into which they had been misled. This kind of openness and enlargement is needed to reconcile, to bring back, the misled or distracted believers to God.

verse.text: You are not constricted in us, but you are [note]1[/note]constricted in your [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]inward parts.
verse.note: The Corinthian believers, being childish ([link]v. 13[/link]), were constricted, contracted, in their inward parts toward the apostles. All children are very narrow in their affection and easily offended by those who correct them.
The same Greek word as for [i]affections[/i] in [link]7:15[/link]. See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Phil. 1[/link].

verse.text: But for a [note]1[/note]recompense in kind, I speak as to [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]children, you also [note]3[/note]be enlarged.
verse.note: The apostle wanted the Corinthian believers to give him a recompense — the same kind of enlarged heart, that they might receive him in their love.
This indicates (1) that the apostle considered the Corinthian believers childish, and (2) that in dealing with them he spoke as a father to his children.

To be enlarged requires growth and maturity in life, which the Corinthian believers lacked ([link]1 Cor. 3:1[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]14:20[/link]). The apostle was laboring on them to make up the shortage. According to the context, which is continued from the end of [link]ch. 5[/link], to be enlarged by growing and maturing in life is equivalent to being fully reconciled to God. Writing in this way, the apostle was carrying out his ministry of reconciling the believers, who were but halfway in being reconciled to God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Do not become [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]dissimilarly yoked with unbelievers. For what [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]partnership do righteousness and lawlessness have? Or what [xref]c[/xref]fellowship does [xref]d[/xref]light have [note]4[/note]with [xref]e[/xref]darkness?
verse.note: This word was spoken by the apostle based on his mouth being opened and his heart being enlarged to the believers in [link]v. 11[/link].

[i]Dissimilarly[/i] means [i]diversely,[/i] implying a difference in kind. This refers to [link]Deut. 22:10[/link], which forbids the yoking together of two dissimilar animals. Believers and unbelievers are diverse peoples. Because of their divine nature and holy standing, the believers should not be yoked together with the unbelievers. This should be applied to all intimate relationships between believers and unbelievers, not only to marriage and business.[br][br]This word indicates that the Corinthian believers were dissimilarly yoked with unbelievers, not separated unto God from worldly people. This means that they were not fully reconciled to God. Hence, the apostle exhorted them not to be dissimilarly yoked with unbelievers but to be separated that they might be fully reconciled, brought back, to God.

The apostle used five illustrations to depict the difference between believers and unbelievers: (1) no partnership, no sharing together, between righteousness and lawlessness; (2) no fellowship, no communion, between light and darkness; (3) no concord, no harmony, between Christ and Belial; (4) no part, no portion, held by a believer with an unbeliever; and (5) no agreement, no consent, between the temple of God and idols. These illustrations also unveil the fact that the believers are righteousness, light, Christ, and the temple of God, and the unbelievers are lawlessness, darkness, Belial (Satan, the devil), and idols.
Lit., toward.

verse.text: And what concord does [xref]a[/xref]Christ have [note]1[/note]with Belial? Or what part does a believer have with an [xref]b[/xref]unbeliever?
verse.note: Lit., toward.

verse.text: And what agreement does the temple of God have with idols? For we are the [xref]a[/xref]temple of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]living God, even as God said, [xref]c[/xref]"I will dwell among them and walk among [i]them;[/i] and [xref]d[/xref]I will be their God, and they will be My people."
verse.note: As the living God, God dwells among us and walks among us to be our God in a subjective way that we may partake of Him (see note [link]15[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Tim. 3[/link]) and be His people, experiencing Him in a living way.

verse.text: Therefore [xref]a[/xref]"come out from their midst and be [note]1[/note]separated, says the Lord, and do not touch [note]2[/note]what is [xref]b[/xref]unclean; and I will [note]3[/note]welcome you";
verse.note: This is to be brought back, to be reconciled, to God in a practical way ([link]5:20[/link]). To be brought back to God, to be reconciled to God, in a practical way requires us to be separated from all persons, things, and matters that do not belong to God.
Things that belong to lawlessness, darkness, Belial, and idols, as listed in [link]vv. 14-16[/link].
This is God's glad receiving of the believers who are brought back, fully reconciled, to Him.

verse.text: "And I will be [note]1[/note]a [xref]a[/xref]Father to you, and you will be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sons and daughters to Me, says the Lord Almighty."
verse.note: God's being a Father to us and our being sons and daughters to Him are matters of life. They are deeper than His being our God and our being His people ([link]v. 16[/link]).
This is the only instance in which the New Testament indicates that God has daughters. For the most part it tells us that the believers are sons of God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore since we have [note]2[/note]these promises, beloved, let us [xref]a[/xref]cleanse ourselves from all [note]3[/note]defilement of flesh and of [xref]b[/xref]spirit, [note]4[/note]perfecting [xref]c[/xref]holiness in the [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]fear of God.
verse.note: This indicates that this verse is a conclusion to the last part of [link]ch. 6[/link], [link]vv. 14-18[/link].
The promises mentioned in [link]6:16-18[/link].
Defilement of flesh is related to being defiled by material things; defilement of spirit, to being defiled by things in the spiritual world, such as idols.

Holiness is separation unto God from all things other than Him (see notes [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link] and [link]4[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link]). To perfect holiness is to make this separation full and perfect, to have our entire being — spirit, soul, and body — fully and perfectly separated, sanctified, unto God ([link]1 Thes. 5:23[/link]). This is to be fully reconciled to God.
Not daring to touch things that do not belong to God or are not related to Him ([link]6:17[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Make room for us; we have [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]wronged no one, we have corrupted no one, we have taken [xref]c[/xref]advantage of no one.
verse.note: The frank exhortation from [link]6:14-7:1[/link] is given parenthetically to bring the distracted believers back to their holy God from their touching of defiling things that they might be fully reconciled to Him. Hence, this verse is actually a continuation of [link]6:11-13[/link], entreating the believers to have their heart enlarged toward the apostles, to make room for the apostles. From this verse to the end of this chapter, the apostle in his entreating expressed his intimate concern for the believers, that they might be consoled and encouraged to go on positively with the Lord after being fully reconciled to Him.
First, have wronged no one; then, have corrupted no one; and last, have taken advantage of no one.

verse.text: I do not say [i]this[/i] to condemn [i]you,[/i] for I have said before that you are [note]1[/note]in our hearts for [i]our[/i] dying together and [i]our[/i] living together.
verse.note: The expression of an intimate relationship.

verse.text: Great is my [xref]a[/xref]boldness toward you, great is my [xref]b[/xref]boasting on your behalf; I am filled with [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]comfort, I overflow with [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]joy in all our [xref]e[/xref]affliction.
verse.note: Lit., the comfort, the joy; pointing to the particular comfort, the particular joy, brought by Titus.

verse.text: For even when we came into [xref]a[/xref]Macedonia, our [note]1[/note]flesh had no rest, but [i]we were[/i] [xref]b[/xref]afflicted in everything; without were [xref]c[/xref]fightings, within were fears.
verse.note: Referring to the outer man, which includes the body and the soul (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]) — the fightings without and the fears within involve the body and the soul. Having no rest in the flesh differs from having no rest in the spirit ([link]2:13[/link]).

verse.text: But He who [xref]a[/xref]comforts those who are [note]1[/note]downcast, [i]that is,[/i] God, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]comforted us by the [note]3[/note]coming of [xref]c[/xref]Titus;
verse.note: Lit., humble; derivatively, downcast (because of oppressive circumstances).

Because of his deep concern for the Corinthian believers' response to his first Epistle, the apostle, having had no rest in his spirit ([link]2:13[/link]) and even being heavily downcast, was anxious to see Titus to obtain information concerning the Corinthians' response. Now Titus not only came but also brought glad news of their positive response. This was a great comfort to the apostle.
Lit., presence. So also in the next verse.

verse.text: And not only by his coming, but also by the comfort with which he was comforted because of you, declaring to us your [xref]a[/xref]longing, your lamentation, your [xref]b[/xref]zeal for me, so that I [xref]c[/xref]rejoiced the more.

For though I caused you [xref]a[/xref]sorrow by the [note]1[/note]letter, I do not regret [i]it.[/i] Even if I [note]2[/note]did regret [i]it[/i] (for I see that that letter, even if for an hour, [note]3[/note]caused you sorrow),
verse.note: Referring to the apostle's first Epistle to the Corinthians.
This indicates that the apostle was not only bold and frank in rebuking the believers in his first Epistle, but was also tender and soft toward them.
This shows that the apostle's first Epistle to the believers had an effect on them.

verse.text: Now I rejoice, not that you were made sorrowful, but that you were made sorrowful to [note]1[/note]repentance; for you were made [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]sorrowful according to God, that in nothing you might suffer loss from us.
verse.note: This was the result the apostle sought in writing his first Epistle.
The apostle's first Epistle made the Corinthians sorrowful according to God, not sorrowful for anything else. This indicates that they had been brought back, reconciled, to God.

verse.text: For sorrow according to God works [xref]a[/xref]repentance unto [note]1[/note]salvation, [i]which is[/i] without regret; but the [xref]b[/xref]sorrow of the world works out death.
verse.note: Referring to being reconciled to God ([link]5:20[/link]), resulting in more life, which is versus death. Through this the apostle saw the fruit of his first Epistle to the believers.

verse.text: For behold this very thing, your being made sorrowful according to God, what [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]earnestness it has [note]2[/note]worked out in you, [note]3[/note]indeed [i]what[/i] [note]4[/note]defense, indeed [i]what[/i] [note]5[/note]indignation, indeed [i]what[/i] [note]6[/note]fear, indeed [i]what[/i] [note]7[/note][xref]b[/xref]longing, indeed [i]what[/i] [note]8[/note][xref]c[/xref]zeal, indeed [i]what[/i] [note]9[/note][xref]d[/xref]punishment! In everything you have commended yourselves to be pure in [note]10[/note]the matter.
verse.note: Or, diligence. Referring to the earnest care of the repentant Corinthian believers toward the apostle, which arose because of his loving concern for their relationship with God and their condition before God. Formerly, they had been careless with regard to the apostle's concern; now in repentance they became careful and earnest regarding it. So also in [link]v. 12[/link].
Or, produced. All seven results produced by the repentant sorrow of the Corinthian believers, as listed in this verse, were a rich reaping from the apostle's first Epistle to them.
Occurring six times in this verse and meaning [i]not only that, but also.[/i]
Or, vindication, clearing of yourselves; referring to the Corinthian believers' vindicating of themselves to Paul through Titus, proving their innocence regarding the offense.
Indignation at the offense and against the offender.
Fear of the apostle, who might come with a rod ([link]1 Cor. 4:21[/link]).
Longing for the apostle. The repentant believers feared the apostle, yet they also had a longing for him.
Zeal to mete out a just punishment to the offender.

I.e., the meting out of justice, the doing of justice to all parties as disciplinary punishment ([link]2:6[/link]).[br][br]The last six results of the repentant sorrow that is according to God fall into three pairs, the first relating to the Corinthian believers' feelings of shame, the second to the apostle, and the third to the offender (Bengel). Wuest's translation also indicates this by the expression "Yes,...in fact," which is used three times as follows: "Yes, verbal defense of yourselves, in fact, indignation, yes, fear, in fact, longing, yes, zeal, in fact, the meting out of disciplinary punishment."
Referring to the matter of incest, which was condemned by the apostle in [link]ch. 5[/link] of the first Epistle.

verse.text: So then, though I [xref]a[/xref]wrote to you, [i]it was[/i] not for the sake of [note]1[/note]him who did the wrong, nor for the sake of [note]2[/note]him who was wronged, but for the sake of [note]3[/note]manifesting to you before God your earnestness for us.
verse.note: The incestuous brother ([link]1 Cor. 5:1[/link]).
The father of the incestuous brother.

The Corinthian believers did love the apostles and did have earnest care toward them, but they had been turned aside by false teachers. Hence, the apostle wrote the first Epistle to bring them back, that their love and earnest care toward the apostles might be made manifest to them.

verse.text: Because of this we have been [xref]a[/xref]comforted. And in addition to our comfort, we [xref]b[/xref]rejoiced [note]1[/note]more abundantly over the joy of [note]2[/note]Titus, because his [note]3[/note]spirit has been [xref]c[/xref]refreshed by all of you.
verse.note: This indicates that the apostle was very human and emotional in his ministering of life.

This major section, from [link]2:12-7:16[/link], concerning the apostles' ministry of the new covenant and concerning themselves as the ministers of the new covenant, begins with the apostle's being anxious to meet Titus because of his loving concern for the Corinthian believers ([link]2:13[/link]), and ends with his being comforted and cheered by Titus's coming with positive news concerning the Corinthians.
This proves that even though the apostles were human and emotional, they still remained in their spirit in their ministering of life.

verse.text: For if in anything I [xref]a[/xref]boasted to him on your behalf, I have not been put to shame; on the contrary, as we spoke all things in truth to you, so also our boasting before Titus turned out to be the truth.
And his [note]1[/note]affections are abundantly toward you, he remembering the [xref]a[/xref]obedience of you all, how you received him with [xref]b[/xref]fear and trembling.
verse.note: Lit., bowels. The same Greek word as for [i]inward parts[/i] in [link]6:12[/link]. See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Phil. 1[/link].

verse.text: I [xref]a[/xref]rejoice that in everything I [note]1[/note]have boldness because of you.
verse.note: Or, am confident in you. Now the apostle was encouraged by the Corinthian believers and could have confidence in them.

verse.text: Furthermore we make known to you, brothers, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of God which has been given in the churches of [xref]b[/xref]Macedonia,
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]. By this grace, which is the resurrection life of Christ, the Macedonian believers overcame the usurpation of temporal and uncertain riches (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 16[/link]) and became generous in ministering to the needy saints.

verse.text: That in much [note]1[/note]proving of affliction the abundance of their joy and the depth of their [xref]a[/xref]poverty abounded unto the riches of their [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]liberality;
verse.note: See [link]2:9[/link] and note 2 there, and note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].
The same Greek word is used for [i]singleness[/i] and [i]simplicity.[/i] See [link]1:12[/link] and [link]Rom. 12:8[/link].

verse.text: That according to [i]their[/i] power, I testify, and beyond [i]their[/i] power, [xref]a[/xref]of their own accord,
With much entreaty they besought of us the [note]1[/note]grace and the fellowship of the [xref]a[/xref]ministry to the saints;
verse.note: The Macedonian believers besought of the apostles the grace that they might participate (have fellowship) in the ministry to the needy saints. They were not asked to have a share in this matter; rather, they begged for it. They considered it a grace that the apostles would allow them such a share.

verse.text: And [i]this,[/i] not as we had hoped, but they [xref]a[/xref]gave themselves [note]1[/note]first to the Lord, [note]2[/note]and to us [note]3[/note]through the will of God.
verse.note: The Lord wants the believers themselves much more than He wants what they have.
They gave themselves not only to the Lord but also to the apostles to be one with the apostles in the accomplishing of their ministry.
It was through the will of God, through the sovereign divine agent, that the believers gave themselves first to the Lord, and to the apostles.

verse.text: So we entreated [xref]a[/xref]Titus that, even as he began before, so also he would complete for you this [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]grace [note]2[/note]as well.
verse.note: The act of giving.
This indicates that besides this grace, the grace of giving, Titus completed other things among the Corinthian believers.

verse.text: But just as you [xref]a[/xref]abound in everything, in faith and in [note]1[/note]word and in [xref]b[/xref]knowledge and in all [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]earnestness and in [note]3[/note]the love in you [note]4[/note]from us, abound in this [note]5[/note]grace also.
verse.note: Or, utterance.
See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].
Some MSS read, the love from you in us.
The love that was in the believers was infused into them from the apostles.

The act of love shown in the giving of material things to the needy saints. The believers' grace was the issue of God's grace, which was motivating them. In the fellowship concerning the ministry to the saints, the apostle referred to the grace of four parties: (1) the grace of God, which was given to the Macedonian believers to motivate them and enable them to give with liberality ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]); (2) the grace of the apostles, which allowed the believers to participate in the ministry to the needy saints ([link]v. 4[/link]); (3) the grace of the believers, which was their ministering of material things to the needy ones ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]); and (4) the grace of Christ, that He became poor that we might become rich ([link]v. 9[/link]). This indicates that the believers' offering of material possessions to the Lord for any purpose should be absolutely a matter of grace, not of human maneuvering.

verse.text: I am [xref]a[/xref]not speaking by way of command but through the earnestness of others, proving also the genuineness of your love.

For you know the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though He was rich, for your sakes He became poor in order that you, because of His poverty, might become [xref]b[/xref]rich.
verse.note: It is grace to us that the Lord Jesus, being rich, became poor for our sakes. In the same principle, it is grace to others that we would sacrifice our material riches for their sakes.

verse.text: And I give [i]my[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]opinion in this matter, for this is profitable for you who were the first to begin [xref]b[/xref]a year ago not only to do [i]this[/i] but even to intend to do [i]this.[/i]
verse.note: The apostle's opinion expressed the Lord's will and desire. See note [link]25[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 7[/link].

verse.text: But now complete also the doing, so that as [i]there was[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]eagerness in intending, so also [i]there would be[/i] the completing out of what you [xref]b[/xref]have.
For if the eagerness is there, it is acceptable according to whatever one has, not according to what he does not have.
For [i]it is[/i] not that to others [i]there would be[/i] relief, [i]yet[/i] to you affliction,
But [i]it is[/i] out of equality; at the present time your abundance for their [xref]a[/xref]lack that their abundance also may be for your lack, so that there may be equality;
As it is written, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"He who [i]gathered[/i] much had no excess, and he who [i]gathered[/i] little had no lack."
verse.note: This quotation from [link]Exo. 16[/link] refers to God's heavenly way of balancing the supply of manna among His people, and is applied here to the ministering of material things to the needy saints. Manna was gathered for the daily supply of God's people; they had a sufficient supply no matter how much or how little they gathered. Gathering manna was their duty, and they were to do their duty without being greedy. In like manner, as children of God we should not be greedy or try to preserve our money for ourselves, for whether or not we give, the outcome will be the same, for God in His sovereignty is active to practice a heavenly balancing of the wealth among His people. The result is that He takes care of our daily needs, so that he who preserves much for himself has no excess and he who preserves little for himself has no lack.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]thanks be to God who puts the same [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]earnestness on your behalf in the heart of [xref]c[/xref]Titus,
verse.note: Or, diligence. Referring to Paul's diligence, earnestness, toward the believers.

verse.text: Because he not only received the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]entreaty, but being more earnest, he also went forth [xref]b[/xref]of his own accord to you.
verse.note: The entreaty of the apostle.

verse.text: And we sent together with him the [xref]a[/xref]brother whose praise in the gospel is throughout [xref]b[/xref]all the churches,

And not only [i]this,[/i] but who has also been selected by the churches as our fellow traveler in this [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace which is being ministered by us, to the [xref]b[/xref]glory of the Lord Himself and [i]to demonstrate our[/i] [xref]c[/xref]eagerness;
verse.note: See notes [link]6[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]7[sup]5[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Avoiding this, that anyone should find fault with us in this [note]2[/note]abundance which is being ministered by us.
verse.note: Money, which is used very much by the devil to seduce man into dishonesty, is involved in the ministry of material things to the saints. In order to avoid being blamed through man's suspiciousness in this matter, the apostles sent with Titus a reputable brother as a witness.
The abundance of material gifts.

verse.text: For we [note]1[/note]exercise foresight for what is honorable not only in the sight of the Lord but also in the sight of men.
verse.note: Or, take forethought for, consider in advance (as in [link]Rom. 12:17[/link]). This must be quoted from [link]Prov. 3:4[/link], where the Septuagint reads, "And exercise foresight for what is honorable in the sight of the Lord, and of men."

verse.text: And we sent with them [note]1[/note]our brother, whom we have proved to be [note]2[/note]diligent in many things many times, yet now much more [note]2[/note]diligent because of the great [xref]a[/xref]confidence [i]he has[/i] toward you.
verse.note: Another faithful brother was sent with the two, that by the mouth of three witnesses a strong testimony might be established ([link]Matt. 18:16[/link]). This displayed the apostle Paul's carefulness in doing things.
Or, earnest.

verse.text: Whether concerning [xref]a[/xref]Titus, [i]he is[/i] my [xref]b[/xref]partner and [xref]c[/xref]fellow worker for you; or our brothers, [i]they are[/i] [note]1[/note]apostles of the churches, [i]they are[/i] Christ's glory.
verse.note: Sent ones, those sent by the churches.

verse.text: Show therefore to them, in the face of the churches, the proof of your love and of our [xref]a[/xref]boasting on your behalf.
For concerning the [xref]a[/xref]ministry to the saints, it is superfluous for me to [xref]b[/xref]write to you;

For I know your [xref]a[/xref]eagerness, of which I [xref]b[/xref]boast on your behalf to the Macedonians, that [note]1[/note]Achaia has been prepared since [xref]c[/xref]last year; and your zeal has stirred up the greater number [i]of them.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: But I sent the [xref]a[/xref]brothers that our boasting on your behalf might not be made void in this respect, that, as I said, you might be prepared;
Lest, if the [xref]a[/xref]Macedonians come with me and find you unprepared, we, not to mention you, be put to shame in this [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]confidence.
verse.note: The Greek word denotes the groundwork on which some superstructure is founded; hence, foundation, ground; thence, confidence. The same Greek word as in [link]11:17[/link].

verse.text: Therefore I thought it necessary to entreat the brothers to go before to you and make ready beforehand your previously promised [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessing, that thus this might be ready [note]2[/note]as a blessing and not [note]2[/note]as [i]a matter of[/i] covetousness.
verse.note: Or, bounty; a willing gift of generosity given as a blessing to others ([link]Gen. 33:11[/link]; [link]Judg. 1:15[/link]; [link]Ezek. 34:26[/link]; [link]Prov. 11:25[/link]).
Willing and generous giving makes the gift a blessing to the receiver; unwilling and grudging giving, withheld by a covetous heart, makes the gift a matter of covetousness to the giver.

verse.text: But [i]take note of[/i] this: He who [xref]a[/xref]sows sparingly shall also sparingly reap; and he who sows with [note]1[/note]blessings shall also with [note]2[/note]blessings reap;
verse.note: Bountiful givings as blessings to the receivers.
Bountiful harvests as blessings from God to the givers.

verse.text: Each one as he has purposed in his heart, [xref]a[/xref]not out of sorrow or out of [note]1[/note]necessity, for [note]2[/note]God loves a [note]3[/note]cheerful giver.
verse.note: I.e., by being forced or pressed.
From [link]Prov. 22:8[/link], where the Septuagint reads, "God blesses a cheerful and liberal man."
Or, hilarious, gleeful.

verse.text: And God is able to make [note]1[/note]all grace abound unto you, that, in everything always having all sufficiency, you may [xref]a[/xref]abound unto every good work;
verse.note: Every kind of grace. See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: Even as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"He has [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]scattered abroad; he has given to the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]poor; his [note]3[/note]righteousness abides forever."
verse.note: As in sowing ([link]v. 6[/link]).
The Greek word denotes one who is obliged to do menial work to eke out a living. It is not the common word for [i]poor.[/i]
Generous giving is, on the one hand, a blessing to the receivers, and, on the other hand, righteousness in the eyes of both God and man.

verse.text: Now [note]1[/note]He who bountifully supplies [xref]a[/xref]seed to the sower and bread for food will supply and multiply your seed and cause the fruits of your righteousness to increase.
verse.note: God cares for His children and feeds them in two ways: in the way of miracles, as shown by the manna, and in the way of natural law, as shown by sowing and reaping. Concerning both of these means of supply, God is the source. He is the One who sends the manna, and He is the One who supplies the seed for sowing and the bread for food. Having a deep realization of these facts and possessing a thorough knowledge of God's economy, the apostle had the assurance and the peace to encourage the impoverished saints in Macedonia ([link]8:2[/link]; [link]9:2[/link]) to give of what they had to meet the needs of others.

verse.text: You in everything are being [xref]a[/xref]enriched unto all [note]1[/note]liberality, which works out through us [xref]b[/xref]thanksgiving to God,
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]. So also in [link]v. 13[/link].

verse.text: Because the [xref]a[/xref]ministry of this [note]1[/note]service is not only filling up the [xref]b[/xref]lack of the saints, but is also abounding through many thanksgivings to God.
verse.note: Priestly service. See note [link]25[sup]3[/sup] in Phil. 2[/link].

verse.text: They, through the [note]1[/note]approving of this ministry, are [xref]a[/xref]glorifying God [i]based[/i] upon the subjection unto the gospel of Christ that [i]issues[/i] from your [xref]b[/xref]confession, and upon the [xref]c[/xref]liberality of the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]fellowship to them and to all;
verse.note: The approving by the needy saints in Judea of the Gentile believers' ministry to them. The Greek word for [i]approving[/i] means [i]test, trial, experiment[/i] (see [link]2:9[/link] and note 1); hence, approving, proof. This indicates that the ministry to the saints will be tested, tried, and approved by the saints to prove the generous character of the ministry.

Or, communication (cf. [i]contribute[/i] in [link]Rom. 12:13[/link], and [i]had fellowship[/i] in [link]Phil. 4:15[/link]). Referring to the ministry of supply, which was a fellowship between the Gentile believers and those in Judea.

verse.text: While in petition on your behalf they also long after you on account of the [note]1[/note]surpassing [note]2[/note]grace of God upon you.
verse.note: I.e., immeasurable.
See notes [link chapter="8"]1[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Thanks be to God for His [note]1[/note]indescribable [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]gift!
verse.note: Lit., not to be told thoroughly.
I.e., the grace given to the believers.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But I myself, Paul, [xref]a[/xref]entreat you through the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]meekness and [note]3[/note]gentleness of Christ, who ([i]as you say[/i]) in [xref]c[/xref]person am [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]base among you, but while absent am [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]bold toward you,
verse.note: [i]But[/i] here indicates a contrast. In [link]chs. 8[/link] and [link book="2 Cor."]9[/link] the apostle spoke pleasantly to the dear saints in Corinth, encouraging them to have fellowship in the ministry to the needy saints in Judea. Immediately after that, he desired to make himself more clear to them by vindicating, with a severe and unpleasant word, his apostleship, even his apostolic authority. This was needed because of the vague and clouded situation caused by the false, Judaistic apostles ([link]11:11-15[/link]), whose teaching and assertion of what they were had distracted the Corinthian believers from the fundamental teachings of the authentic apostles, and especially from the proper realization of Paul's standing as an apostle.

To be meek is to be mild toward men, without resisting or disputing. This indicates that the apostle, being firmly attached to Christ ([link]1:21[/link]) and being one with Him, lived by Him, behaving in His virtues.
Denoting humility, yieldingness, approachableness. See notes [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in Phil. 4[/link] and [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Tim. 3[/link].
A word used in ancient times by pagans to express contempt for the Christian virtue of humility.
Or, of good courage. The apostle was bold, having courage to speak out in his Epistle the real situation.

verse.text: I beseech [i]you[/i] that when [xref]a[/xref]present I would not have to be [xref]b[/xref]bold in the confidence with which I count myself, to dare do to some who count us as ones who are walking [xref]c[/xref]according to flesh.
For though we walk [note]1[/note]in flesh, we do not [xref]a[/xref]war according to flesh;
verse.note: Being human, the apostles were still in flesh; hence, they walked in flesh. But, especially in spiritual warfare, they did not walk according to the flesh; they walked according to the spirit ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]).

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]weapons of our [xref]b[/xref]warfare are [note]1[/note]not fleshly but [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]powerful before God for the [xref]d[/xref]overthrowing of strongholds,
verse.note: Since spiritual warfare is not against flesh but against spiritual forces ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]), the weapons should not be fleshly but spiritual. Such weapons are powerful to overthrow the strongholds of the enemy.
I.e., powerful in God's view, divinely powerful; hence, exceedingly powerful.

verse.text: As we overthrow [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reasonings and every [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]high thing rising up against the knowledge of God, and take [xref]c[/xref]captive every [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]thought unto the [xref]e[/xref]obedience of Christ.
verse.note: Reasonings and thoughts are in and of the mind. These are the strongholds of Satan, God's adversary, within the minds of those who are disobedient to God. Through the spiritual warfare, reasonings must be overthrown and every thought must be taken captive to obey Christ.

The haughty things within the reprobate mentality that are against the knowledge of God. These too must be overthrown by the spiritual weapons that they might no longer rise up against the knowledge of God.

verse.text: And we are ready to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]punish all disobedience when your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]obedience is fulfilled.
verse.note: This is a bold and severe word with a rebuke.
Our obedience affords a base from which the Lord can deal with others' disobedience.

verse.text: You look at things [xref]a[/xref]according to [i]their[/i] appearance. If someone [note]1[/note]has confidence in himself to be [xref]b[/xref]of Christ, let him take account of this again concerning himself, that even as he is [xref]c[/xref]of Christ, [xref]d[/xref]so also are we.
verse.note: This indicates that to be of Christ is an important matter. It is vital to the Christian life and ministry.

verse.text: For even if I should [xref]a[/xref]boast somewhat more abundantly concerning our [xref]b[/xref]authority, which the Lord has given for [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]building [i]you[/i] up and not for overthrowing you, I will not be put to shame.
verse.note: Apostolic authority, in contrast to people's consideration in their natural concept, is not for ruling over the believers but for building them up.

verse.text: I say this so as not to seem as if I am terrifying you through my letters,
Because while his letters, [i]someone[/i] says, are weighty and strong, his [xref]a[/xref]bodily presence is [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]weak and his [xref]c[/xref]speech [note]2[/note]contemptible.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 2[/link].
Or, of no account. Lit., made nothing of.

verse.text: Let such a one take account of this, that such as we are in word by letters when absent, such also [i]we are[/i] in deed when present.

For we do not [xref]a[/xref]dare to class or compare ourselves with any of those who [xref]b[/xref]commend themselves; but they, measuring themselves by themselves and comparing themselves with themselves, are without understanding.

But we will [note]1[/note]not [xref]a[/xref]boast beyond [i]our[/i] measure but [note]2[/note]according to the measure of the [note]3[/note]rule which the God of measure has [xref]b[/xref]apportioned to us, to reach even as far as you.
verse.note: The apostle was bold, but not without limit. This shows that he was under the restriction of the Lord. His boasting was according to the measure of the rule which the God of measure, the ruling God, had apportioned to him.

Paul's ministry to the Gentile world, including Corinth, was according to the measure of God ([link]Eph. 3:1-2[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:8[/link]). Hence, his boast was within this limit and, in contrast to that of the Judaizers, was not without measure.
Lit., measuring rod. Like the rule of a carpenter.

verse.text: For we are not [note]1[/note]extending ourselves beyond our bounds, as if we did not reach you, for we were the first to [xref]a[/xref]come even as far as unto you in the [xref]b[/xref]gospel of Christ.
verse.note: As the Judaizers did.

verse.text: [i]We are[/i] [xref]a[/xref]not boasting beyond [i]our[/i] measure in [xref]b[/xref]others' labors, but have the hope, as your faith is increasing, to be [note]1[/note]magnified in you according to our rule unto abundance,
verse.note: By being enlarged, increased. The apostles had the hope that through the growth of the Corinthian believers' faith, the apostles' ministry would be magnified (in the sense of being praised) by being enlarged and increased abundantly, yet still according to the rule, the measure, that God had apportioned to them.

verse.text: So that we may announce the gospel unto those parts beyond you, not so that we may boast in another man's rule in things [i]already[/i] prepared.
But he who [xref]a[/xref]boasts, let him boast in the Lord;
For [i]it is[/i] not the one who [xref]a[/xref]commends himself who is [xref]b[/xref]approved, but the one whom the Lord commends.
I wish that you would [xref]a[/xref]bear with me in a little [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]foolishness; but indeed you do bear with me.
verse.note: Referring ironically to the apostle's forced self-vindication and boasting.

verse.text: For I am jealous over you with a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]jealousy of God; for I [xref]b[/xref]betrothed you to one husband to [xref]c[/xref]present [i]you as[/i] a pure [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]virgin to Christ.
verse.note: Like the jealousy of a husband over his wife.
To be the bride for the Bridegroom ([link]John 3:29[/link]), the wife of the Lamb ([link]Rev. 19:7[/link]).

verse.text: But I fear lest somehow, as the [xref]a[/xref]serpent [xref]b[/xref]deceived [xref]c[/xref]Eve by his [xref]d[/xref]craftiness, your [note]1[/note][xref]e[/xref]thoughts would be corrupted from the [note]2[/note][xref]f[/xref]simplicity and the [xref]g[/xref]purity toward Christ.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

Or, singleness. Referring to the believers' single-hearted loyalty, single-minded faithfulness, toward Christ. In the garden of Eden, Eve, the wife of Adam, was deceived by the serpent, Satan, through his questioning and undermining of God's word, and was thus carried away to the tree of knowledge and distracted from the simplicity of eating the tree of life ([link]Gen. 3:1-6[/link]). Here the church in Corinth, the pure virgin betrothed to Christ, was being deceived by the Judaizers, the ministers of Satan ([link]v. 15[/link]), who were undermining God's word by preaching another Jesus, a different spirit, and a different gospel ([link]v. 4[/link]). Because of this undermining preaching, the apostle was fearful that the Corinthians would be distracted by the teachings of the Judaizers and would be separated from the genuine appreciation, love, and enjoyment of the precious person of the Lord Jesus Christ Himself as their life and their everything. The above-mentioned three things preached by the Judaizers, who intermingled with the believers, were of Satan.

verse.text: For if indeed he who comes preaches [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]another Jesus, whom we have not preached, or you receive a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]different spirit, which you have not received, or a [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]different gospel, which you have not accepted, you [xref]d[/xref]bear [note]2[/note]well with [i]him.[/i]
verse.note: Another Jesus means another person; a different spirit means a spirit of a different nature; and a different gospel means a gospel of a different kind.

Or, beautifully, ideally. Used here ironically. In [link]v. 1[/link] the apostle expressed his desire that the Corinthian believers, who were bearing with him, would bear more with him. Now in this verse he referred them to the fact that they were bearing beautifully with the false apostles. His idea here was, "Since you bear with the false apostles so well, so beautifully, so ideally, please bear more with me."

verse.text: But I count myself to be inferior to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]super-apostles in nothing.
verse.note: I.e., apostles in surpassing degree. An ironic reference to the false apostles, mentioned in [link]v. 13[/link] and in [link]12:11[/link], who surpassed the degree of the genuineness of the apostles. The false apostles were the Judaizers who came to Corinth to preach another Jesus with a different spirit in a different gospel.

verse.text: But even if I am a [note]1[/note]layman in [xref]a[/xref]speech, yet I am not in [xref]b[/xref]knowledge; indeed in every way we have made [i]this[/i] [xref]c[/xref]manifest in all things to you.
verse.note: One who is unlearned, not having the utterance derived from special training.

verse.text: Or did I commit a sin, abasing myself that you might be exalted, because I announced the gospel of God to you [xref]a[/xref]free of charge?
I robbed other churches, taking wages for the ministry to you.

And when I was present with you and [xref]a[/xref]lacked, I was not a [xref]b[/xref]burden to anyone; for the brothers who came from [xref]c[/xref]Macedonia [xref]d[/xref]filled up my lack, and in everything I kept myself from being [xref]e[/xref]burdensome to you, and will keep [i]myself.[/i]
The [note]1[/note]truthfulness of Christ is in me, that this [xref]a[/xref]boasting shall not be stopped as it regards me in the regions of [xref]b[/xref]Achaia.
verse.note: As in [link]Rom. 3:7[/link] and [link]15:8[/link], truthfulness is an attribute of Christ, as are meekness and gentleness in [link]10:1[/link]. Since the apostle lived by Christ, whatever Christ is became his virtue in his behavior.

verse.text: Why? Because I do not [xref]a[/xref]love you? God [xref]b[/xref]knows.
But what I do, I also will do, that I may cut off the opportunity of those desiring an opportunity, that in the thing in which they boast, they may be found even as we.
For such ones are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]false apostles, deceitful [xref]b[/xref]workers, [note]2[/note]transfiguring themselves into apostles of Christ.
verse.note: The super-apostles ([link]v. 5[/link]; [link]12:11[/link]).
Or, fashioning, disguising (and so in [link]vv. 14-15[/link]). The false apostles, being deceitful, fashioned themselves into the appearance of the real apostles, who were true in every way.

verse.text: And no wonder, for [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Satan himself transfigures himself into an [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]angel of light.
verse.note: This indicates that Satan is the source of the false apostles. They followed him in his deceitfulness to frustrate God's economy.
God is light, and His angels are of light. In contrast, Satan is darkness, and all his followers are in darkness. There is no fellowship between light and darkness ([link]6:14[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore it is no great thing if also his ministers transfigure themselves into [note]1[/note]ministers of righteousness, whose [xref]a[/xref]end will be according to their works.
verse.note: These are the true apostles, who carry the ministry of righteousness ([link]3:9[/link]). Whatever the ministers of Satan do is altogether unrighteous. Righteousness has no partnership with lawlessness ([link]6:14[/link]).

verse.text: Again I say, Let no one think me to be [xref]a[/xref]foolish; but if otherwise, accept me even as if I were foolish, that I also may [xref]b[/xref]boast a little.
What I speak, I speak not according to the Lord but as if in [xref]a[/xref]foolishness, in this [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]confidence of boasting.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: Since many [xref]a[/xref]boast according to the [xref]b[/xref]flesh, I also will [xref]c[/xref]boast.
For you [xref]a[/xref]bear gladly with [xref]b[/xref]fools because you [i]yourselves[/i] are [note]1[/note]wise.
verse.note: An ironic expression applied to the Corinthians.

verse.text: For you bear [i]it[/i] if anyone [xref]a[/xref]enslaves you, if anyone [xref]b[/xref]devours [i]you,[/i] if anyone [note]1[/note]takes [i]you,[/i] if anyone [xref]c[/xref]lifts himself up, if anyone beats you in the face.
verse.note: I.e., takes you as a prey (the same word as for [i]caught[/i] in [link]Luke 5:5[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]By way of self-disparagement I say [i]this,[/i] [note]2[/note]Supposedly we ourselves were [xref]a[/xref]weak. But in whatever anyone [i]else[/i] is daring, I speak in [xref]b[/xref]foolishness, I also am [xref]c[/xref]daring.
verse.note: This is ironic.
Lit., As though.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hebrews are they? I also. [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Israelites are they? I also. The [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]seed of Abraham are they? I also.
verse.note: [link]Verses 22-23[/link] give a comparison between the apostle and the Judaizers, pointing out clearly that in addition to his needing to enjoy Christ as his life supply, implied in all the preceding chapters, a genuine minister of Christ needs to suffer in following the Lord. Anyone, like the Judaizers, who lacks these two qualifications must be recognized as a false apostle, a minister of Satan, regardless of his claims of apostolic authority ([link]vv. 13-15[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Ministers of Christ are they? I speak as being [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]beside myself, I more so! In [xref]c[/xref]labors more abundantly, in [xref]d[/xref]imprisonments more abundantly, in [xref]e[/xref]stripes [note]2[/note]excessively, in [xref]f[/xref]deaths often.
verse.note: Lit., out of my mind.
Lit., above measure.

verse.text: Under [i]the hands of[/i] the Jews five times I received [xref]a[/xref]forty [i]stripes[/i] less one;
Three times I was beaten with [note]1[/note]rods, once I was [xref]a[/xref]stoned, [note]2[/note]three times I was [xref]b[/xref]shipwrecked, a night and a day I have spent in the deep;
verse.note: While the stripes in [link]v. 24[/link] were meted out by the Jews, rods here were used by the Romans ([link]Acts 16:22-23[/link]).
These three instances, which do not include the shipwreck at Melita (universally recognized as Malta), are not recorded in the Acts.

verse.text: In journeys often, in dangers of [note]1[/note]rivers, in dangers of [note]2[/note]robbers, in dangers from [i]my[/i] [xref]a[/xref]race, in dangers from the Gentiles, in dangers in the [xref]b[/xref]city, in dangers in the wilderness, in dangers in the sea, in dangers among [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]false brothers;
verse.note: Rivers that are subject to violent and sudden changes from the sudden swelling of mountain streams or the flooding of dry watercourses.
"The tribes inhabiting the mountains between the table-land of Asia Minor and the coast were notorious for robbery" (Vincent).
Mainly the Judaizing Christians.

verse.text: In [xref]a[/xref]labor and hardship; in [note]1[/note]watchings often; in [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]hunger and thirst; in [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]fastings often; in [note]3[/note]cold and [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]nakedness —
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

Since [i]fastings[/i] is listed here with [i]hardship,[/i] it must refer to involuntary fasting because of a lack of food. Such fasting differs from hunger. Hunger here may refer to a situation in which there is no way to obtain food; involuntary fasting may refer to a situation of poverty.
Because of the weather and insufficient clothing.
Referring to a state of being insufficiently clothed or naked because of scourging or shipwreck.

verse.text: Apart from the things which [i]have[/i] [note]1[/note]not [i]been mentioned, there is this:[/i] the crowd [i]of cares[/i] pressing upon me daily, the [note]2[/note]anxious concern for [xref]a[/xref]all the churches.
verse.note: Have not been mentioned in [link]vv. 23-27[/link].
Anxious care, or care. The same Greek word as for [i]anxiety[/i] in [link]Matt. 13:22[/link] and in [link]1 Pet. 5:7[/link].

verse.text: Who is [xref]a[/xref]weak, and I am not weak? Who is [xref]b[/xref]stumbled, and [note]1[/note]I myself do not [note]2[/note]burn?
verse.note: Or, I myself am not burned.
Burn in sorrow and indignation over the cause of the stumbling.

verse.text: If I must [xref]a[/xref]boast, I will boast of the [note]1[/note]things of my [xref]b[/xref]weakness.
verse.note: Referring to the apostle's sufferings and hardships, which made him appear low, weak, and contemptible in the eyes of his adversaries. These things, not the strength of which his adversaries boasted, attested that he was a true apostle.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]God and Father of the Lord Jesus, He who is [xref]b[/xref]blessed forever, [xref]c[/xref]knows that I am [xref]d[/xref]not lying.
In [xref]a[/xref]Damascus, the [note]1[/note]governor under Aretas the king [xref]b[/xref]guarded the city of the Damascenes in order to seize me;
verse.note: Lit., ethnarch.

verse.text: And in a basket I was [xref]a[/xref]lowered through a window, through the wall, and escaped his hands.

To [xref]a[/xref]boast is [note]1[/note]necessary, [i]though[/i] indeed not [xref]b[/xref]expedient; yet I will [note]2[/note]come to [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]visions and [xref]d[/xref]revelations of the Lord.
verse.note: The apostle was forced to boast, because of the Corinthians' folly. Though it was not expedient for him, it was necessary for their profit. For their building up, he had to boast, that they might be brought back to a sober and proper understanding concerning their relationship with the apostle.
Meaning that Paul would now come to boast of the visions and revelations that he had received from the Lord.

Revelation is the putting aside of the veil, the unveiling of hidden things; vision is the scene, the view, seen at the unveiling. Many things concerning God's economy and administration in the universe were hidden. The Lord revealed, unveiled, these to the apostle, and he received visions of these hidden things.

verse.text: I know a [note]1[/note]man [xref]a[/xref]in Christ, fourteen years ago (whether in the body I do not know, or outside the body I do not know; God [xref]b[/xref]knows) such a one was [note]2[/note]caught away [note]3[/note]to the [note]4[/note]third heaven.
verse.note: The apostle ([link]v. 7[/link]), not as the old creation but as the new creation ([link]5:17[/link]). In this section the apostle desired to boast of the new creation in Christ by boasting of his weaknesses in the flesh, the old creation ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]9[/link]).
The same Greek word as in [link]v. 4[/link], [link]Acts 8:39[/link], and [link]1 Thes. 4:17[/link].
Lit., until within; i.e., as far as.

The visible clouds may be considered the first heaven, and the sky, the second heaven. The third heaven must be the heaven above the heavens, the highest heaven ([link]Deut. 10:14[/link]; [link]Psa. 148:4[/link]), where the Lord Jesus and God are today ([link]Eph. 4:10[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:14[/link]; [link]1:3[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And I know such a man (whether in the body or [note]2[/note]outside the body, I do not know; God knows),
verse.note: The conjunction [i]and[/i] is an important word here. It indicates that what is mentioned in [link]vv. 3[/link] and [link]4[/link] and what is mentioned in the preceding verse are two different matters. [link]Verse 2[/link] tells us that the apostle was caught away to the third heaven. Now, [link]vv. 3[/link] and [link]4[/link] tell us something further, that the apostle was caught away also to another place, into Paradise. This indicates strongly that Paradise is not the same as the third heaven in [link]v. 2[/link]; it refers to a place other than the third heaven.
Some MSS read, apart from.

verse.text: That he was caught away into [note]1[/note]Paradise and heard unspeakable words, which it is [xref]a[/xref]not allowed for a man to speak.
verse.note: The pleasant section of Hades, where the spirits of Abraham and all the just are, awaiting the resurrection ([link]Luke 16:22-23[/link], [link]25-26[/link]), and where the Lord Jesus went after His death and stayed until His resurrection ([link]Luke 23:43[/link]; [link]Acts 2:24[/link], [link]27[/link], [link]31[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:9[/link]; [link]Matt. 12:40[/link]). This Paradise differs from the Paradise in [link]Rev. 2:7[/link], which will be the New Jerusalem in the millennium. In this section the apostle told of the exceeding greatness of the revelations he had received. In the universe there are mainly three sections: the heavens, the earth, and Hades, which is underneath the earth ([link]Eph. 4:9[/link]). As a man living on earth, the apostle knew the things of the earth. But men do not know the things either in the heavens or in Hades. The apostle, however, was brought away to both of these unknown places. Hence, he received visions and revelations of these hidden regions. For this reason he mentioned these two uttermost parts of the universe.

verse.text: On behalf of such a one I will [xref]a[/xref]boast, but on behalf of myself I will not [xref]b[/xref]boast, except in my [xref]c[/xref]weaknesses.

For if I desire to [xref]a[/xref]boast, I will not be foolish, for I will [xref]b[/xref]speak the truth; but I refrain lest anyone account of me [i]something[/i] above what he [xref]c[/xref]sees me [i]to be[/i] or [xref]d[/xref]hears from me.

And because of the [note]1[/note]transcendence of the revelations, in order that I might not be exceedingly [xref]a[/xref]lifted up, there was given to me a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]thorn in the flesh, a messenger of [xref]c[/xref]Satan, that he might [note]3[/note]buffet me, in order that I might not be exceedingly lifted up.
verse.note: Or, superabundance, exceeding greatness, excess.

"Frequent in classical Greek in the sense of a pale or stake" (Vincent), or a "sharp pointed staff" (Alford). Here it might refer to a kind of physical suffering, such as the trouble with his eyes (see note [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 4[/link]).
To beat with clenched fist, differing from [i]buffet[/i] in [link]1 Cor. 9:27[/link], which means [i]to beat under the eye.[/i]

verse.text: Concerning this I entreated the Lord [xref]a[/xref]three times that it might depart from me.

And He has said to me, My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace is sufficient for you, for My [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]power is perfected in [xref]c[/xref]weakness. Most gladly therefore I will rather boast in my weaknesses that the [xref]d[/xref]power of Christ might [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]tabernacle over me.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]. Sufferings and trials are often ordained by the Lord for us that we may experience Christ as grace and power. Hence, in spite of the apostle's entreaty, the Lord would not remove the thorn from the apostle.

For the sufficiency of the Lord's grace to be magnified, our sufferings are required; for the perfectness of the Lord's power to be shown forth, our weakness is needed. Hence, the apostle would most gladly boast in his weaknesses that the power of Christ might tabernacle over him. Grace is the supply, and power is the strength, the ability, of grace. Both are the resurrected Christ, who is now the life-giving Spirit dwelling in us ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]) for our enjoyment.

The Greek word for [i]tabernacle over[/i] is a compound verb composed of two words. The first word means [i]upon,[/i] and the second, [i]to dwell in a tent,[/i] as in [link]John 1:14[/link] and [link]Rev. 21:3[/link]. The compound verb here means [i]to[/i] fix a tent or a habitation upon. It portrays how the power of Christ, even Christ Himself, dwells upon us as a tent spread over us, overshadowing us in our weaknesses.

verse.text: Therefore I am [note]1[/note]well pleased in [xref]a[/xref]weaknesses, in [note]2[/note]insults, in [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]necessities, in [xref]c[/xref]persecutions and [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]distresses, on behalf of Christ; for when I am [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]weak, then I am [note]5[/note]powerful.
verse.note: Or, well content; the same Greek word as in [link]Matt. 3:17[/link].
Or, mistreatments.
Or, constraints; i.e., urgent needs that press much. See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 7[/link].
Lit., narrowness of room; hence, straits, difficulties, distresses.
Weak in his old being; powerful in the overshadowing Christ.

verse.text: I have become [xref]a[/xref]foolish; you yourselves have compelled me. For [i]it is[/i] I [i]who[/i] should have been [xref]b[/xref]commended by you; for in nothing am I inferior to the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]super-apostles, even though I am [xref]d[/xref]nothing.
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: Indeed the [note]1[/note]signs of an [xref]a[/xref]apostle were wrought among you in all [xref]b[/xref]endurance by [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]signs and [note]3[/note]wonders and [note]4[/note]works of power.
verse.note: The attesting miracles that furnish credentials of apostleship.
Attesting miracles.
Startling and awakening miracles.
Miracles that demonstrate God's power.

verse.text: For what is there in which you were [note]1[/note]treated in a manner inferior to the rest of the churches, except that I myself was not a [xref]a[/xref]burden to you? [note]2[/note]Graciously forgive me this [note]2[/note]injustice!
verse.note: Or, inferior to, weaker than.
These are ironic expressions.

verse.text: Behold, this [xref]a[/xref]third time I am ready to come to you, and I will not be a burden; for I do [xref]b[/xref]not seek what is yours but you. For the [xref]c[/xref]children ought not to store up for the parents, but the [xref]d[/xref]parents for the children.
But I, I will most gladly [note]1[/note]spend and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]be utterly spent on behalf of your souls. If I [xref]b[/xref]love you more abundantly, am I loved less?
verse.note: Meaning to spend what he has, referring to his possessions.
Meaning to spend what he is, referring to his being.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]let it be [i]so![/i] I did [xref]a[/xref]not burden you; but, [i]as some of you say,[/i] being [note]2[/note]crafty, I took you by guile.
verse.note: I.e., let the former matter go.
Some Corinthians charged the apostle with this. They said that he was crafty in making gain, that he was indemnifying himself by sending Titus to receive the collection for the poor saints.

verse.text: Did I take [xref]a[/xref]advantage of you through anyone whom I have sent [xref]b[/xref]to you?

I entreated [xref]a[/xref]Titus and sent with [i]him[/i] the [xref]b[/xref]brother. Titus did not take advantage of you, did he? Did we not walk in the same [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]spirit? In the same [xref]d[/xref]steps?
verse.note: Our regenerated spirit indwelt by the Holy Spirit. This spirit governs, rules, directs, regulates, and leads us in our Christian walk ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]). The apostles walked in such a spirit.

verse.text: All this time you have been thinking that we are defending ourselves to you. [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Before God [xref]b[/xref]in Christ we speak; but all things, beloved, [i]are[/i] for your [xref]c[/xref]building up.
verse.note: [i]In Christ[/i] points to the life by which the apostles spoke, and refers to the means and substance of their speaking. [i]Before God[/i] points to the atmosphere in which the apostles spoke and refers to the sphere of their speaking.

verse.text: For I [xref]a[/xref]fear that perhaps when I come, I may find you not such as I wish, and I may be found by you not such as you wish; that perhaps [i]there may be[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]strife, jealousy, outbursts of anger, [xref]c[/xref]selfish ambitions, [note]2[/note]slanders, [note]3[/note]whisperings, [note]4[/note]demonstrations of being puffed up, [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]tumults;
verse.note: Or, debate, contention, quarrel.
Or, detractions, evil speakings.
Secret slanders.
Inflated arrogance.
Or, disturbances.

verse.text: That when I come again my God may humble me before you and I may mourn over many who have [xref]a[/xref]sinned before and who have not [xref]b[/xref]repented of the [xref]c[/xref]uncleanness and [xref]d[/xref]fornication and licentiousness which they have practiced.
This [xref]a[/xref]third time I am coming to you; at the mouth of two or three [xref]b[/xref]witnesses shall every word be established.

I have previously said and I say beforehand, when I was present the second time and being [xref]a[/xref]absent now, to those who have [xref]b[/xref]sinned before and to all the rest, that if I come again, I will [xref]c[/xref]not spare,
Since you seek a proof of the Christ who is speaking in me, who is not weak unto you but is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]powerful in you.
verse.note: Christ was powerful in the believers while He was speaking in the apostle. This was indeed a strong and subjective proof to the believers that Christ was speaking in the apostle.

verse.text: For indeed He was [xref]a[/xref]crucified out of [note]1[/note]weakness, but He [xref]b[/xref]lives [note]2[/note]by the power of God. For indeed [note]3[/note]we are [xref]c[/xref]weak in Him, but we will [xref]d[/xref]live together with Him [note]2[/note]by the [xref]e[/xref]power of God [i]directed[/i] toward you.
verse.note: Weakness of the body; the same as in [link]10:10[/link]. For Himself, Christ did not need to be weak in any way, but for accomplishing redemption on our behalf, He was willing to be weak in His body that He might be crucified. However, after being resurrected, He now lives by the power of God.
Lit., out of.

The apostles followed the pattern of Christ and were willing to be weak in the organic union with Him that they might live with Him a crucified life. Thus they would live together with Him by the power of God directed toward the believers. Apparently, they were weak toward the believers; actually they were powerful.

verse.text: Test yourselves whether you are in the [note]1[/note]faith; [note]2[/note]prove yourselves. Or do you not realize about yourselves that [note]3[/note]Jesus Christ is [xref]a[/xref]in you, unless you are [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]disapproved?
verse.note: The objective faith ([link]Acts 6:7[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:19[/link] and note 3). If one is in the objective faith, he surely has the subjective faith, believing in Christ and the entire content of God's New Testament economy. This is what the apostle asked the Corinthians to test.
To test is to determine one's condition; to prove is to verify that one meets the qualifications for a particular status.
As long as a believer realizes that Jesus Christ is in him, he is qualified, approved, as a genuine member of Christ.
I.e., disqualified.

verse.text: But I hope that you will know that [note]1[/note]we are not disapproved.
verse.note: By this word the apostle turned to himself and the other apostles, indicating that they, having Christ living and speaking in them, were fully qualified and not disapproved, especially among the troublesome Corinthians. The apostle earnestly hoped that they might recognize this and have no further questions about him.

verse.text: Now we pray to God that you do nothing wrong, [note]1[/note]not that we may appear approved, but that you yourselves may do what is good and we may be as if disapproved.
verse.note: This indicates that the believers' doing good proved the qualifications and teaching of the apostles. However, the apostle did not care to use this as a ground for exercising his apostolic authority to discipline them; he cared for their doing good that they might be established and built up.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For we are not able [i]to do[/i] anything against the [note]2[/note]truth but [i]rather[/i] for the truth.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that [link]v. 8[/link] is an explanation of what is mentioned in the preceding verse. The apostle expected the Corinthian believers to do good, but not so that the apostles would appear approved. To edify the believers to do good is for the truth, but for the apostles to cause themselves to appear approved and to defend themselves to the believers ([link]12:19[/link]) is against the truth. The Lord would not enable the apostles to do this; hence, they were not able to do it.
The reality of the contents of the faith. See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Tim. 2[/link].

verse.text: For we rejoice whenever we are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]weak and you are powerful; this also we pray for, your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]perfecting.
verse.note: To be weak here is the same as to appear disapproved. When the apostles appeared disapproved, they were weak in administering discipline to the believers. When the believers did good, they were powerful and made the apostles powerless to discipline them. The apostles rejoiced over this and prayed for this, i.e., for the believers' perfecting.

Or, restoring. Implying repairing, adjusting, putting in order again, mending; perfectly joining together (cf. [link]1 Cor. 1:10[/link] and note 4), thoroughly equipping, well furnishing; thus, perfecting, completing, educating. The apostles prayed for the Corinthians that they might be restored, put in order again, and thoroughly equipped and edified to grow in life for the building up of the Body of Christ.

verse.text: Therefore I write these things while being [xref]a[/xref]absent in order that when [xref]b[/xref]present I would not [i]have to[/i] use [xref]c[/xref]severity, according to the [xref]d[/xref]authority which the Lord has given me for [xref]e[/xref]building up and not for overthrowing.

Finally, brothers, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rejoice, be [note]2[/note]perfected, be [note]3[/note]comforted, [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]think the same thing, be [note]5[/note]at [xref]c[/xref]peace; and the [xref]d[/xref]God of [note]6[/note]love and peace will be with you.
verse.note: Since the apostles were rejoicing ([link]v. 9[/link]), they were able to exhort the believers also to rejoice. This was not to be done in their natural life but in the Lord ([link]Phil. 3:1[/link]; [link]4:4[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 5:16[/link]).

Or, completed thoroughly. I.e., repaired or adjusted, put in order again, mended, perfectly joined together; thus, restored. In Greek this word is the root of the word for [i]perfecting[/i] in [link]v. 9[/link] and in [link]Eph. 4:12[/link].

The apostles were comforted by the God of all comfort ([link]1:3-6[/link]). The Corinthians were very discouraged by the apostle's first Epistle to them. Now, in the second Epistle, he comforted them with the comfort of God ([link]7:8-13[/link]).

Thinking the same thing must have been the main thing in which the distracted and confused Corinthians needed to be perfected, adjusted, put in order, and restored, as the apostle had exhorted in his first Epistle ([link]1 Cor. 1:10[/link]).
At peace with one another, and probably with God also.

The Corinthians were lacking in love ([link]1 Cor. 8:1[/link]; [link]13:1-3[/link], [link]13[/link]; [link]14:1[/link]) and were short of peace because they were disturbed by the distracting teachings and confusing concepts. Hence, the apostle wished that the God of love and peace would be with them for their adjusting and perfecting. They needed to be filled with the love and peace of God that they might walk according to love ([link]Rom. 14:15[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:2[/link]) and have peace with one another ([link]Rom. 14:19[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:14[/link]).

verse.text: Greet one another with a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]holy kiss.
verse.note: A kiss of pure love without any contaminating mixture.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]All the saints greet you.
The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of the Lord Jesus Christ and the [xref]b[/xref]love of God and the [xref]c[/xref]fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all.
